review: A burst of celluloid adrenaline, "M:I - Rogue Nation" is thrilling from beginning to end without sacrificing story.This time around, Ethan Hunt and his crew are on the run from the CIA, following disbandment as he tries to prove the existence of the Syndicate, an international criminal consortium.Like usual, Tom Cruise fully commits to his portrayal of Ethan Hunt and in "Rogue Nation" manages to astound with his commitments to stunts and an occasional well-placed zinger.His supporting team gels excellently with Cruise, but this time around it's Rebecca Ferguson that breaks out and almost steals the movie with her seductive, athletic portrayal."Rogue Nation" continues the "M:I" renaissance with thrilling results.

The Mission: Impossible series continues to surge in Rogue Nation. The sequel's innovative action-sequences, thrilling story and performances is exhilarating and surprising; continuing to breath life in this improving franchise. 4.5/5

It's official, Ghost Protocol has rebooted MI into a smashing action/espionage success with this follow up.RN is everything you need in an action film. Great set pieces, smart plot, clever humor, somewhat relateable/humane characters, a robust competent cast, good direction...I almost feel like it's too similar in quality to GP though. The pacing, action, dialogue, even the way each character moves almost seems surgical now. Don't get me wrong it's a great film and like I said, everything you'd ever NEED but I think we've hit a level of stagnation here.There's no more wow factor, there's nothing iconic that you would recall for years on down the road. Rogue Nation will be remembered by most as a blur of exceptional action film making...I believe the next MI film will need more personal, resonating character moments from the IMF crew if it's going to succeed.

There's not a lot to think about here, just your typical summer motion picture thrill ride, but it's got the goods insofar as that goes. Cruise supplies the action, Simon Pegg provides the light buddy comedy, but the film really belongs to Rebecca Ferguson who purposefully is given equal footing with the man in this. Hell, she saves the hero in this. Twice. Are you ready for that? And she dances backward. In heels. She's the break out star here, and the reason to watch, (after the action set pieces). All systems go.

This electrifying chapter is possibly the best and most well constructed film of this successful franchise so far, with an intelligent espionage plot, a fantastic editing job (I could really swear that Brian De Palma directed that splendid opera scene) and exhilarating action scenes.
Mission Impossibpe has greatly improved from the first way back when. More sophisticated, enjoyable, entertaining and amusing! A thoroughly enjoyable movie shouldnt be missed!

Tom Cruise and company are the nucleus of this franchise, the plot-lines the outer membrane. That's not to say the narrative is bad or anything, but it feels meaningless when you are having so much fun watching an action set piece set to opera. 'Rogue Nation' is a solid addition to a franchise that has proven reliable at crafting a wholly satisfying blockbuster.

Not as outlandishly crazy as the Fast and the Furious series, not as beholden to tradition as the Bond series, the Mission: Impossible series doesn't get the same notoriety but I'd declare it the most consistent and best action franchise going today. Each new film is a distillation of their director's strengths, keeping things fresh, and the mainstay is Tom Cruise in prime action hero mode and risking his life like a madman. While not as dizzyingly entertaining as 2011's Ghost Protocol, Rogue Nation is another fun and action-packed spy thriller with terrific and memorable set pieces. The plot involves Ethan Hunt (Cruise) and his team on the run, again, as their agency is shut down for its reckless methods. A rival agency known as The Syndicate is plotting political assassinations, so Hunt and his team (Simon Pegg, Jeremy Renner, Ving Rhames) must work along the fringes to save the day. The newest addition is Swedish actress Rebecca Ferguson as a mysterious ally and antagonist for Hunt. She's smart, formidable, and not treated as a romantic interest or overly sexualized (progress). After Alicia Vikander's superb performance in Ex Machina, and now Ferguson's steely turn, it's quite a booming year for Swedish imports. The series' star is still Cruise and his cavalier treatment of his 50-year-old body in the pursuit of the daredevil stunts. The opening with Cruise attached to the outside of an ascending cargo plane is a stunning image jolted by the charge of realism. An underwater vault break-in is wonderfully developed. The snazzy car chases, motorcycle chases, and foot chases all benefit from Cruise being front and center. Say what you will about the man but he's a movie star. The biggest problem with Rogue Nation is much like Ghost Protocol in that it peaks in the middle. The last act takes place entirely in London and it just can't compare with what came earlier, which leaves the movie lumbering to a close with its rather substandard villain. Even with a less than stellar conclusion, Rogue Nation is another entertaining, fun, and thrilling action movie that would be the best the summer has to offer if it weren't for the highs of Mad Max. Nate's Grade: B+

This is actually the first MI movie I have ever seen, but it won't be the last. The trick with action movies is to make the action scenes unique. We've seen car chases and explosions before, and this film has many of those, but it also throws in underwater heists, a man flying on the outside of a plane and some nice humor. Like almost all action flicks, the story itself is not much to marvel at, so in order for an action film to be good it has to make up for it in other ways, which absolutely Rogue Nation does. And despite what people say or think about Tom Cruise, there is no denying that he is a bonafide action star.

Continuing the upward growth, "Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation" takes all of the elements that people loved from the best and worst "Mission Impossible" films, and lays them all on the table to enjoy. This time, the team is left with nothing as a nation-gone-rogue is after Ethan Hunt. With so many more layers, this film has one of the best stories of the franchise. With a very bond-esque inspiration, this is not one to miss if you are a fan of the series. Tom Cruise is fantastic once again as the charismatic lead in Hunt, and the entire cast (namely Simon Pegg) are all noteworthy here as well. With a very carefully written script, direction that is off the charts, and editing that makes each action piece make your heart pump, this picture has it all. There may be a few pacing issues, but this is definitely one of the best films you will see this summer!

Another fantastic entry in the rare case of an action franchise that just keeps getting better and better. That's thanks to great direction of excellent action in awesome set pieces, but also thanks to the leading man. People can say about Cruise's private life or religious choices all they want. The man keeps delivering great genre entertainment year after year, while doing as many stunts as he can all by himself. The insane opening sequence is testament to that. Still, one of the best parts of this is how it is an ensemble piece with everyone doing their part. Female newbie Rebecca Ferguson is fantastic, blowing all Bond girls from the last 45 years out of the water. Pegg is likable and funny as always. The pacing is great and especially the two major sequences in the middle of the film in the Vienna opera and Casablanca are absolutely breathtaking. The showdown can't even begin to top that and doesn't try, taking a different approach to a solution instead. Overall a pretty long film for an action thriller but an incredibly entertaining one. With quality as high as this, they can keep making these until kingdom come.

Christopher McQuarrie and Tom Cruise display another successful teamup with Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation.This action adventure delivers for its entirety. For over 2 hours, the story drops the action when needed, unleashes the thrills when asked for, reveals the secrets at opportune moments, and even finds the time for a bit of humor in between. The storyline manages to keep it going with moment after moment.The action is well rounded. Shootings, hand to hand combats, and vehicle carnage thrown in for good measure.Tom Cruise knows what he is doing and when surrounded with the likes of Jeremy Renner, Simon Pegg, and Ving Rhames, it 's hard to go wrong. To top it all off, Rebecca Ferguson is an absolute bombshell addition to the cast.Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation is a top of the line action adventure. This review will self destruct in 5 seconds.

With such a high bar after Ghost Protocol, this plays more like a Mission: Mediocre for me. The high reviews and praise as being the best in the series really baffle me, because the plot overall was very vanilla and straightforward. I thought they played too many of their cards in the trailers, because pretty much any stunt (aside from details of the third act) has already been mostly revealed over the course of the trailers. The plane stunt is amazing, and the driving and motorcycle stuff is amazing, but aside from those scenes, nothing really leaves a lasting imprint for me. I feel like they strung a bunch of spy and stunt scenes together without much setup, whereas in Ghost Protocol there was dialogue and setup to the scenes and they had more substance. Overall, I'd still say it's a decent, be it a little disappointing, entry into the franchise (my 3rd favorite), but I'll need a re-watch of the original and Ghost Protocol to get my enthusiasm for the series back up to the level it was at.

Even if it hasn't the glossy action set pieces of the fourth installment nor can't reach the psychological depth of the first one, Ethan Hunt and his team can ease the wait for Bond's return with a tight, thrilling and endlessly twisty adventure.

IN DE PALMA THEIR HANDS - My Review of MISSION IMPOSSIBLE: ROGUE NATION (4 Stars)Sometimes, and I mean rarely, a blockbuster well into its franchise just works. Think about how CASINO ROYALE reinvigorated the 007 Series, with Daniel Craig and director Martin Campbell bringing a healthy dose of gravitas to something that had long-before resorted to trashy silliness. But, again, that kind of thing happens as often as Halley's Comet. Imagine my surprise then when writer/director Christopher McQuarrie and Tom Cruise reunited for this fifth installment and went in guns blazing. This is a thrilling action movie, effortlessly jumping from set piece to set piece with deliciously shifting loyalties and some tightly-wound suspense. It's not going to change the world, but it definitely sends a warning shot to all the other Studio Tentpole makers to up their game and at least stay engaged with the swill they're shilling. MISSION picks up a short time after the Kremlin-destroying events of GHOST PROTOCOL, with our hero, Ethan Hunt (Cruise) desperately trying to get to a plane before it takes off. Yes, the filmmakers blow their poster wad within the first five minutes, giving us that indelible and real shot of Cruise dangling from the side of a plane in mid-air. My instant thought was, "That's pretty ballsy. I hope they have more tricks up their sleeves or else this thing is an early climaxer!"Turns out, it was just an appetizer, and when we come back from credits, we find the IMF (Impossible Mission Force) in disarray and losing its power, with Hunt having gone dark in the field. A perfect time for the Syndicate, a band of terrorists hellbent on world domination, to set their plot in motion. Of course they have to go through Ethan and his loyal band of spies, and we all know how that tends to work out for the bad guys. Joined again by Jeremy Renner, Simon Pegg and Ving Rhames, Cruise and company find themselves in a race against time to save the world. The story, as usual, is somewhat irrelevant, but the execution of the thrills and chills thoroughly won me over. Without spoiling anything, we're treated to torture, an attempted assassination at an opera, a thrillingly-edited underwater sequence, and a good half dozen more scenes before the film almost literally dumps you out, spent and exhausted. Bringing an ambiguous dose of tension is Rebecca Ferguson, excellent as the femme fatale who may or may not be on Ethan's side. It's this push-pull that gives the film its effervescent kick. I've enjoyed Cruise's performances in recent years because he's become more willing to give us the aging action star who suffers aches, pains, and real fear. He may ultimately prevail, but there's a cost nowadays. Battle fatigue often plays better than superhuman strength, something the world of MARVEL and DC COMICS could stand to learn. Beautifully shot by master cinematographer Robert Elswit, who ruled 2014 with stellar work on NIGHTCRAWLER and INHERENT VICE, and edited with rare patience by Eddie Hamilton, ROGUE NATION seldom resorts to the style of seizure-inducing scenes in most giant CGI nightmares. Instead, much effort has been put into understanding each location and who is doing what to whom. Trust me, that just does not happen much anymore. McQuarrie also gets credit here, using alternate scenarios to get what's normally droning exposition across to the viewers. The preparation for the underwater scenes, for example, made great use of dispensing complicated information by way of showing Simon Pegg suffering the outcome of a mission that could go horribly wrong. This and the stunning opera scene reminded me of vintage Brian De Palma, who in addition to making such suspense classics as DRESSED TO KILL and BLOW OUT, happened to direct the first MISSION installment. De Palma understands screen geography better than most and he's always infused his scenes with a somewhat winking, knowing, dreamlike energy. McQuarrie seems to pull from the same playbook, perhaps to honor his predecessor's work on the series, or maybe it's because he just thinks De Palma has done cheese correctly. Either way, what we have here is very De Palma-esque. For a director like De Palma, who has often been criticized for being too Hitchcock-esque, MISSION IMPOSSIBLE: ROGUE NATION seems to give him his long-deserved due...even if he had nothing to do with it.

The fifth installment of the franchise, Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation delivers an exciting, adrenaline-packed adventure. After the IMF is disbanded secret agent Ethan Hunt goes rogue in order to complete one last mission to expose a criminal syndicate of former spies turned mercenaries. Tom Cruise, Jeremy Renner, and Simon Pegg return, and are joined by Rebecca Ferguson and Alec Baldwin. And their performances are pretty good; particularly Ferguson, whose stunt work and fight scenes are especially well-done. Director Christopher McQuarrie also does an impressive job, and brings a lot of suspense and tension to the action sequences. Thoroughly entertaining, Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation is an explosive spy thriller.

Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation fails to add anything particularly new to the franchise, with its plot being recycled from other spy films over the past few years. That said, Rogue Nation is a tight, well made action films, with terrific stunts, fun humor, and a climax that doesn't suffer from being overly big or exhausting. Rogue Nation may be overly familiar, but it is an incredibly fun blockbuster that's certainly worth the price of admission.

Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation is a brilliant action film, perfectly combining the series epic set pieces with a solid storyline to match. This is a film that was never boring and keeps you engaged thanks to director Christopher McQuarries sharp direction. Everything from the opening plane sequence, to the fantastic bike chase, this has all the action and intensity you want from a Mission: Impossible film. The story isn't anything groundbreaking, but its a cool idea thats executed very well. It gives the opportunity for the great characters to develop further and to see them do awesome stuff. It also works very well to give the incredible action scenes a lot more impact. Tom Cruise continues to prove he is one of the best action stars in the business, no matter the age. His performance shows yet again that he was born to play Ethan Hunt, bringing all the charisma and fun to the role that we expect. Ving Rhames is a much welcome return to the franchise, although I had almost wished he had more to do amd more interaction with Ethan. Simon Pegg is great as usual, using a likable personality and humor to make a fun character. Jeremy Renner also continues to prove that he is just awesome. Rebecca Ferguson really came out of nowhere and blew me away, and I hope this leads her into new roles I get to see her in soon. The villain was a solid baddie to take on, as I liked his cold and calculating personality. He at least was better than the majority of other villains in this franchise. Overall, I love the Mission: Impossible franchise and I think the argument could be made that Rogue Nation is the best yet. These films only seem to be getting better. But thanks to brilliant action sequences, a great cast once again proving their brilliant chemistry, a well done script, and a new director who blends all of this together perfectly to create one of the best films of the summer. Whether or not you are a fan of spy films, you definitely should go see this.

Intense, and surprising very good. MI: The Rogue Nation was definitely a thriller, and cements Tom Cruise's status still as leading man in action films. The casting was excellent, and the camaraderie was obvious. The film was very well paced, and packed with good humour, great action, and great direction. Loved it.
These Mission Impossible films are impossible to not enjoy. Another great installment with a heart racing plot and awe inspiring stunts.

Mission Impossible is back again! The first 3 installments of this series, led by Cruise, set such a high bar that to try and continue the series without him led to an utter flop. But with Cruise back at the helm, the movie picks up right where part 3 left off, and continues the successful story.The action scenes are genuinely epic, the supporting cast definitely add up to more than just the sum of their parts, and the whole production just has a nostalgic feel to it that's very appealing. Sometimes it's hard to imagine how the next instalment will fare compared to the ones preceding it, but MI-RN does more than enough to uphold the reputation of the original MI movies.

It is kind of amazing that this series has maintained itself as one of the more enjoyable action/adventure film series out there. It just tends to have a good little spy thriller plot with lots of goofy fun action scenes, and it never seems to take itself so seriously that you get annoyed with it. It knows it is ridiculous, and winks a little at you, but it never verges into camp territory...just a perfect tone for these kind of movies. The fact that they also employ lots of real stunts by Cruise is certainly a plus too. I'm not the biggest Cruise fan (as he is always playing Tom Cruise), but this series is really the perfect vehicle for him to play that Tom Cruise character and showcase his wacky stuntwork. This wasn't quite as good as the last film, but it was pretty close. I was glad they brought back most of the supporting cast from the last movie and gave Rhames a better role to play. My only complaint is that they seem to fallback on the "we're all alone without Government backing for some reason or another" trope. Just make an action/adventure and not need to be lone wolves having to prove the need for the IMF.

Man, these past 2 MI movies have been great. Very well made and fun action movies. The plot was kind of all over the place, like they usually are, but I could still follow what was going on. I know he's in his 50's now, but you would never know it. My only real problem with the movie is that there is only one female character. ONE. It's a total guyfest outside of the one female agent. Sure, she's in the movie a lot, but it's still weird. Hopefully, if there's another one, they'll balance the scales a bit more.

-Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation is een 2015 Amerikaans actie spionnen film co-geschreven en geregisseerd door Christopher McQuarrie. Het is de vijfde film in de Mission: Impossible film serie. De film sterren Tom Cruise, Jeremy Renner, Simon Pegg, Rebecca Ferguson, Ving Rhames, Sean Harris en Alec Baldwin met cruise, Renner,Pegg en Rhames hun rollen hernemend uit de vorige films. Rogue Nation wordt geproduceerd door Cruise, J. J. Abrams, en David Ellison van Skydance Productions. In de film, IMF agent Ethan Hunt (Cruise) is op de vlucht voor de CIA, na de IMF-ontbinding als hij probeert te bewijzen het bestaan van het syndicaat, een internationale geheimzinnige terroristische consortium.--Kritische reactie:-Bij de herziening aggregator Rotten Tomatoes, Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation heeft een waarde van 93% positieve reviews, gebaseerd op 261 reviews, met een gemiddelde score van 7,5/10. De site's kritische consensus luidt: "Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation blijft de franchise's spannende herleving - en bewijst dat Tom Cruise een ster blijft zonder gelijke." Metacritic geeft de film een score van 75 uit 100, gebaseerd op 46 critici, met vermelding "algemeen gunstige beoordelingen".Op CinemaScore, publiek heeft de film een soort "A-" op een A tot F-schaal.- Vervolg:-Op mei 2015, Paramount was de ontwikkeling van een zesde Mission: Impossible film met cruise, Abrams, Ellison en Goldberg terug te produceren, samen met Don Granger en Matt Grimm executive producering en Elizabeth Raposo toezicht op ontwikkeling. Kort voor de release van Rogue Nation, Cruise kondigde aan dat hij voor een zesde film zou terug keren, verklarend dat de productie in 2016 kan beginnen. Volgend Cruise's statement, Paramout bevestigd ook dat er een zesde film in opkomst is. In december 2015, McQuarrie kondigt aan dat hij zal terugkeren naar de zesde film voor de directie en Ferguson zal haar rol hernemen als Ilsa Faust ook.
A storyline which is too flamboyant to feel real & exciting .. I've watched all the Mission Impossible & James Bond movies, & this is one of the most boring for me.

As exhilarating as it was intelligent, Rogue Nation was a spectacular follow-up to the Mission: Impossible series we've all grown to love.

Tom Cruise is awesome. There's just no other way to put it. He's a movie star the way that Cary Grant was a movie star: pure class, pure suave, supercool, attractive. And like old Cary, he's not incredibly versatile. With a few exceptions, if Tom Cruise is in your movie, he'll be playing Tom Cruise, it doesn't matter what his character's name is. But he is always 100% committed to the role and gives it everything he's got. He also, and this point can't be overstated, looks hella cool when he runs, which is good because he runs a lot. Like, in almost every movie he does, he'll end up booking it at some point. It's super hard to run and look cool, believe me. Most people look ridiculous when they're clipping along at full speed. Not my boy Tom. In Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation, Tom runs, but he also flies, speeds, fights, shoots, suffocates and dies. And given the fact that he is renowned for doing all his own stunts, he probably actually did die on set. MI:5 is a continuation of the last film, but only insofar as it is the next impossible mission the impossible mission's gang must face. Really, you could walk into MI:5 without having seen any of the previous films and be just fine. Like the TV show 24, each mission movie more or less stands as its own little novella, rather than as a chapter of a complete novel. This time around CIA grumpy pants Alec Baldwin goes before the Senate to have IMF shut down, complaining that the covert operatives are irresponsible and unneeded. The problem is, Tom Cruise's Ethan Hunt has just discovered a rogue faction of the British Intelligence that effectively do what IMF does, but for evil rather than good. In order to keep on their trail and stop them before world domination can take place, Hunt goes rogue himself, with the CIA hot on his heels. Over the top action set pieces ensue. MI:5 is a hell of a lot of fun. There's a lot of talky talk, more so than I remember there being in the previous couple films, and as such the movie could have easily been ten minutes shorter and worked a little tighter. But the talking is sandwiched between sequences of such impressive action bravado that by the time you start to feel a little restless, you're hit with a 'wow' moment and forget all about it. Unfortunately that 'wow' factor is diluted a bit by the fact that all those cool set pieces have already been ruined in the trailer. Don't get me wrong, Tommy boy hanging from a cargo plane 5,000 feet above the solid ground is awe inspiring. As is his helmet-less high speed chase on a winding mountain on racing bikes. As is his high speed car chase through a busy city in some far off land. But all that insanity was in the trailer. I understand that the marketing department over at Paramount Pictures want to cause the mouths of millions of action fans to water, but far too often these days I check out a movie that looks awesome from its trailer, only to find that all the good bits were in that trailer (I'm looking at you Minions). Something the makers of these Impossible movies have going for them is that there is nothing they can come up with that is too far. When your whole franchise rests on the idea of each film being more impossible than the last, that pretty much gives you free range to throw that entire kitchen sink right on in there. In Rogue Nation, things certainly become pretty impossible for IMF. Of course, we know they will prevail, if for no other reason than that Tom Cruise had already signed on for a sixth instalment by the time this one hit the screens. But I can't say I felt the same sense of danger that I had with Ghost Protocol or MI:3. The problem is that there isn't as much substance in between the boomshuckaluck. Those talking scenes I mentioned are quite procedural and the love interest angle feels tacked on. As a result, this isn't a film that you will find yourself thinking about by the time your popcorn induced stomach ache has worn off. But, those are subjective quibbles and at the end of the day, if you're looking for a couple hours of high energy and high excitement, Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation is your ticket.

Some people have been saying Rogue Nation ups the ante from Ghost Protocol, but I think it more or less maintains the status quo.I wouldn't hazard to say the film was mind-blowing or anything, I more just think the Mission Impossible films are just pretty solid in their pacing in the way a James Bond flick is - there's usually a pretty good twist at the 2/3 mark and good, well-choreographed action with a really large-scale stunt sequence.The neat thing Rogue Nation does is kind of dissolve the infrastructure of the MI films in the plot and that makes it a little more thrilling and there's TWO big stunts. Both are really nice, especially with the knowledge that Tom Cruise did them more or less for real.I just want something truly surprising to happen, not just more spy film fare. Like let's kill off the star or something... I don't know, with this franchise there's always just the safety that Tom Cruise is safe and that seems like a crutch.Either way, a pretty fun thrill ride - just not a reinvention of the wheel.

McQuarrie is - despite his Oscar-winning script for the delightfully twisty THE USUAL SUSPECTS - a no-nonsense writer. Dude gets right to the point (see Valkyrie and Jack Reacher for examples.) Which is something this franchise needed. It's nice to have a fairly straightforward Mission: Impossible outing. However, when you don't have to piece the plot together it leaves ample time for nit-picking other details, namely the director's lack of experience. Yes, the film is filled with action and adventure, but it's a bit uneven, even rushed at times, and overall fails to stand out. Compared to the fun, ever-coiling tension of De Palma's outing, the sheer adrenaline of Abrams', and the masterful packaging of Brad Bird's, there's just nothing special here, aside from the increased use of Simon Pegg. (Though, to be fair, at least it doesn't fall into the trying-too-hard, over-the-top realm of embarrassment that John Woo's outing did.) It's still a solid spy movie, and I had fun watching it, but it fails to distinguish itself from its classmates, namely the Bond franchise. Maybe next time.Also, as much as I hate to say it, Alec Baldwin might be ruined for me. I don't think I'll ever be able to watch him in anything and not see Jack Donaghy. All of his scenes feel like they should be funny, which is a personal failing on my part... but it also pulled me out of the movie.
Always on Top! Good job Tom! What next?

Who would've thought the best movie of the Summer was gonna be one of the last and one of the least buzzed about? In this fifth installment in the series the IMF (now disbanded) must hunt down a league of rogue agents known as The Syndicate. As much as I love Mission Impossible III, I may have to give Rogue Nation a nudge to the top spot in the series. First off, the action. It is as intense and impressive as the trailers would suggest. The underwater mission will have you gasping for air yourself and the car chase rivals the creativity of chases we saw in Furious Seven earlier this year. Then there's the cast. Tom Cruise delivers as he always has in this series but it is even more impressive now that he is in his early fifties and still performing many of his own stunts. Simon Pegg and Rebecca Ferguson stand out the most, both having a lot to do given these films are marketed as Cruise's vehicles. The rest of the cast fairs well enough, but those three actors have the most to do and none of them disappoint. From a technical standpoint MIRN is a beauty. Cinematographer Robert Elswit crafted some gorgeous shots in this thing. In fact, shortly into the film I took notice as to how every shot in the film seemed to be lined up meticulously. Eddie Hamilton deserves credit as well for his tight editing. Even at 131 minutes the movie "cruises" by. I really couldn't name a scene I would drop, the whole thing just grabs its audience and doesn't let go until the credits roll. Now to our new director-Christopher McQuarrie. After the success of Ghost Protocol, many were expecting Brad Bird to return for the sequel. Bird wanted to make Tomorrowland, and uber-producer J.J. Abrams (director of MI3) was too busy with Star Wars to direct (though he did produce). Cruise suggested his Jack Reacher director Christopher McQuarrie. I knew McQuarrie could handle the suspense and tension of the franchise. As for the action? I was unsure if Jack Reacher and Way of the Gun (his only previous directing efforts), while they contained action, were proof enough that he could take on the grand level of action required by this franchise. But I was glad to see a creative choice and someone I knew Cruise worked well with behind the camera. And boy did he prove he could handle the action. Like I said earlier, the action set pieces on display here are stunning. And what makes them all the better is the lack of noticeable CGI. The filmmakers worked hard to use as many practical effects as they could and it shows, really adding to the realistic feel and making the movie all the more intense. I guess if I had to complain about something it would be score. The majority of the score just feels like rehashes of old MI movies and videogames. While a familiar MI music cue here and there is to be expected, the lack of truly original music is a bit disappointing. Still, minor complaint in a spectacle this enjoyable. Personally, I saw this on an IMAX screen. Now, it serves the big screen well. But what really stands out in the theater is the sound. This is some very impressive sound editing and mixing. So, if you're not going to see it on a large-format screen like IMAX or BigD, just make sure you seek a theater that has exceptional sound quality. I don't care if you're not a fan of the franchise, if you're not a fan of Cruise, if the trailers didn't impress you-stop making excuses. If you like action, if you like spy thrillers, this is the movie for you. 9/10

It's a slick, fast moving machine that never takes itself too seriously. Tom Cruise is on top form as he seemingly always is, even this far into his career he still performs incredible stunts and conjures up on-screen charisma like its nothing. Newcomer Rebecca Ferguson provides a solid screen presence and gives it her all, never going autopilot and letting Cruise (control) take over. Comedic relief is not given to one particular character, which would have been quite easy with an actor like Simon Pegg at your disposal. Instead, Alec Baldwin and Jeremy Renner get many chances to stretch their comedic muscles, and it doesn't need to be said that in the case of Baldwin this is always a good thing. Ving Rhames makes a brief appearance as Luther Stickell, although I was quite disappointed he wasn't utilised more. He is another actor with impressive comedic talent, as seen in his single-handed saving of Scorsese's Bringing Out the Dead, and I think they perhaps could have had more of him instead of just having him there as a callback to the original films and giving him his paycheck and then pulling a disappearing act.The action is inventive, intertwined with comedy, and performed with a kinetic energy that never runs out. Sean Harris as the villain doesn't do much outside of looking sinister, but he does that well enough. The story takes the much used "the IMF is being disbanded" plot device but tinkers with it enough to make it new. Its fun, its a 2 hour ride with characters you'll wish you were friends with, its sizzling entertainment at the movies.

The latest entry into the mission impossible series may just be the best one yet. You best believe they pulled out all the stops for this one with great performances from Cruise, Pegg and Ferguson it's hard to go wrong. Fantastic thrill ride throughout and perfectly paced, which is hard to find with action movies these days. That's why I welcome this movie, it refreshing to see a well done action movie that's funny, dramatic, emotional and with good directing. Fans of the series will not be disappointed and will only be left wanting to see more.

This movie was incredible, the best spy movie of the year, in a year filled with good spy movies. A genuine roller-coaster ride, with an engrossing blend of action, humor and suspenseful intrigue. The cast is excellent throughout; Rebecca Ferguson is a particular standout as Ethan Hunt's foil. The plot is twisty and keeps you guessing. Incredible, impossible setups deliver great payoffs throughout. I don't think there was a boring frame in the entire film.Tom Cruise deserves special mention. Think what you want to about his personal life, but there is no other star actor working today who puts this much commitment and dedication into his craft. He plays his character to absolute perfection, and lends great authenticity by performing his own stunts. The airplane scene featured on the poster really happens, and it's really Cruise clinging to the side of that airplane, and it is breathtaking to watch. No visual effects, no CGI, just reality. Amazing.Only Mad Max beats this movie in the action category this year. A must-see for all action movie fans.

Ethan Hunt and co return in a typically explosive, action packed adventure, although this time focusing on a unique terrorist threat... Okay so the basis of the story has perhaps been done before. I fully expected this however, and was more interested in the inventive action sequences and plot twists that can be found in previous MI films. These came in abundance, and whilst it was annoying not being able to decide which side certain characters were on, it did keep me guessing until the very end. Once again Simon Pegg provides a light hearted and comic addition to the cast. His enjoyment of the role shines through, making his reactions and acting appear particularly genuine. A burst of celluloid adrenaline, "M:I - Rogue Nation" is thrilling from beginning to end without sacrificing story.This time around, Ethan Hunt and his crew are on the run from the CIA, following disbandment as he tries to prove the existence of the Syndicate, an international criminal consortium.Like usual, Tom Cruise fully commits to his portrayal of Ethan Hunt and in "Rogue Nation" manages to astound with his commitments to stunts and an occasional well-placed zinger.His supporting team gels excellently with Cruise, but this time around it's Rebecca Ferguson that breaks out and almost steals the movie with her seductive, athletic portrayal."Rogue Nation" continues the "M:I" renaissance with thrilling results.

Mission Impossible is turning out to be one of those rare franchises that just keeps getting better. I wasn't a huge fan of the first two films, but when J.J. Abrams came on board for the third he set the series in the right direction. The fifth entry, Rogue Nation, takes everything that worked about the previous films and manages to raise the bar even higher. What makes this series stand out from Bourne and similar films in the genre is the sense of fun and humour these later sequels have (bringing Simon Pegg into the mix sure didn't hurt). Rogue Nation delivers in every way possible...an engaging script, beautiful locations, great performances, plenty of twists, jaw-dropping stunts. As impressive as it is seeing 53-year-old Tom Cruise strap himself to a plane as it takes off, it's actually newcomer Rebecca Ferguson who steals every scene she's in. Crazy action, tons of fun, great story...Mission Impossible is becoming that summer blockbuster franchise that knows how to do everything right, and it definitely gets my vote for one of the year's best films.

The Mission Impossible has come a long way from the days of pointless action and ludicrous plot to a new breed of spy that has its own ground...This new MI dares to go bold, to go do thing where...well some has been done before but we miss it so muchThe new James Bond series with Daniel Craig has been about realism and fewer gadgets. But with MI you see all the amazing and cartoonish gadgets we once loved in James BondThe truth is that MI is basically now a mix of modern spy with the goofiness of the old ones. In fact, it's what SPECTRE wanted to be but couldn't. Although, a little more serious then it would be SPECTREThe new MI is unique to itself the action the dialogues the villain...oh the villain.Truthfully I can't think of any other villain in MI history who has been this calculating, this intimidating and it's a shame that he has so many few scenes. But whenever he is there, he steals the show.And let's not forget Rebecca Ferguson who is a tremendous addition and I love to see her again. True, she doesn't have much chemistry with Tom Cruise but in the movie it's never implied that they love each other or have feelings anyway. They just flirt. And that's fine. Kind of needed. Not every woman is for doing it.The rest of the cast are kind of sidelined and only there as plot devices but nevertheless they do their jobs well. Especially Simon Pegg who is real heart of this series.As for the conflict between CIA and MI, well I wanted that to have more depth and be more complex as the concerns were again raised and actually happened in this movie but well, it didn't and it's a missed opportunity.Of course the main plot and theme is what it has been for five movies so far but, well we kinda expected it didn't we? Mission Impossible Rogue Nation combines imaginary and lunatic action and creates amazing scenes even though there's no way Tom Cruise would survive that backflip in BMW or even walk away with no blood!!! But still, that's what I meant by being a mix of old and newTrue, Mission Impossible IS taking a lot of cues from new James Bond movies and it's obvious. Especially the Villain and...this one I had to say.... BMW that opens to fingerprint and someone else tries and fails??? That handgun in Skyfall? Anyone??While it takes many cues from Skyfall and others I don't mind it that much because it helps them progress and it's fineIf MI series' next movie uses another great villain that has some screen time or the same villain we saw here but in bigger capacity. And uses awesome action like it did with this movie...I think we may have another winner too.Frankly, MI should remain goofy with a lot of action. No deep storytelling because well, never established anything that mysterious and then again...this is Mission Impossible...let's be crazy!Overall, this movie achieves what Ghost Protocol did and created something that on some grounds falls short of Ghost Protocol and some grounds raises the bar.While it raised the bar in Villain, threat, women and of course actionIf failed at keeping the attractive realism, stop rehashing stuff or "inspirations" and not using a great villain.But still, the twists, the mystery the action made this Mission Impossible one to remember for a long time...until next one comes out anyway.Great Job and Congrats to all who made this movie. You made a modern James Bond of the Old.Impressed and hope next one will do the same.

Cruise's Ethan Hunt could so easily have gone down the way of a US version of the pompous James Bond, yet like Cruise himself, there is just something about the MI films that make them so entertaining without even seeming like its trying.Wisely, Rouge Nation sets up what is arguably the films biggest set piece - that insane plane scene you saw in the trailer - right at the beginning of the film. Go big or go home as the saying goes... and Cruise does it well. He continually reminds us throughout Rouge Nation that he is part of that dying breed of cinema actor, one who is willing to commit to the project at all costs.That gusto is part of what makes Rouge Nation so much fun. The movie doesn't stretch the imagination of the espionage narrative too far, so it's the witty banter between the characters, the great action scenes that anchor the enjoyment of the film and the air of effortless tongue-in-cheek acknowledgement of the ridiculousness of the plot throughout Mission Impossible that always makes this hard to resist.

This is not going to end well.A secret agency known as the syndicate has formed as a British intelligence agency that wants to put IMF down. The CIA also wants IMF put down. "Are you questioning my loyalty or ability?""I can't decide."Christopher McQuarrie, director of The Way of the Gun, Jack Reacher, and another scheduled Mission Impossible project, delivers Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nations. The storyline for this picture is fairly blah, straightforward, and predictable. The acting and action is very mediocre. Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation is probably my favorite so far in the series. It is nothing original, but simply the manifestation of perfected formula. It's characters, plot elements and many ideas were handpicked from a bin of action movie cliches, but they are gathered together to create a film with undeniable style. It has very sharp, elegant visuals of high tech heists and high class operas coupled with a thrilling, subtly dark energy. We've seen everything in this movie many times before, but it's so well-done here that it's hard to criticize. It has genuinely awesome, gripping action sequences, such as the shootout at the opera, the replacement of the chip in the underwater vault and the final chase scene that ends with Lane in a glass box, which was brilliant. Part of the reason the film succeeds is also its intelligence. Instead of performing crazy stunts and blowing up everything, the impossible mission here involves making very clever decisions in the face of difficult circumstances. The film makes you think, something few action films do.The acting is good, but generic and there are little dashes of humor here and there along with some seldom hiccups of awkward/corny dialogue. Ethan Hunt is hard to relate to because he is such a mythic, unrealistic character, "the manifestation of destiny". He gets away with everything. The narrative is largely derivative because you know at the end everything will tie up into a perfect knot. Another strength of the film is the leading lady because she is the most complex character in the film. She provides an intriguing and emotionally engaging performance, unlike the stock action heroes the film is populated with. We relate to her because she's caught in limbo between two sides and we can't figure out who's side she's on. She's also a talented fighter who's capable of defending herself in a film dominated by men. It's refreshing to see a strong female role in an action film and Rebecca Ferguson brings grace and cool confidence to the movie.

Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation had big shoes to fill following Ghost Protocol, but it easily stepped up, with excellent set pieces and plenty of action. This isn't a step forward for the series as the past film was, but more of a continuation. This is by no means a bad thing. The formula doesn't feel tired yet, and with plenty of twists, great betrayals and character moments, I was thoroughly entertained from beginning to end. The movie does have some shortcomings, however. The villain is a caricature, and I frankly didn't find him very threatening. We don't get the sense of scope that previous M:I films have provided, so the stakes don't feel as high. With that said, the script is great, with lots of funny quips, as well as a new character, played by Rebecca Ferguson, who feels right at home in the ensemble. If you haven't already, check this one out for a quick witted action film that is a feast on the eyes, as well as an intelligent take on the well worn spy genre. 4 out of 5 stars.

This is the best Mission Impossible yet! Everything in this movie works, from the fantastic, edge of your seat opening, to the incredible finale, this movie is awesome. The action scenes are well filmed and well directed. It doesn't rely on quick cuts and closeups like a lot of action movies rely on. Director Christopher McQuarrie is perfect behind the camera and was a very good choice to helm this movie. The highlight of the movie has to be an incredible car/motorcycle chase in the middle of the movie. It's so well filmed as well as being captivating and thrilling. The movie benefits a lot from starring Tom Cruise. He is one of the most dedicated actors and because he does 95% of his own stunts, the movie is able to use better shots during action scenes instead of having to figure out ways of hiding the stunt double's face.Speaking of Cruise, the performances are excellent. In addition to his expert stunt work, Cruise gives a stellar performance. You can tell he cares a lot about the role and he gives a very strong performance. Simon Pegg is also very good. He doesn't get enough credit as a dramatic actor. He plays a lot of comedies, he's often the comedic relief, but he is also a great dramatic actor. Go back and watch Shaun of the Dead or Hot Fuzz, and while those are comedies, during the "dramatic parts" you can tell he has some chops. Here he shows it again. He has some acting chops on him. The other one that needs mentioning is Rebecca Ferguson. She is also very good as a conflicted spy and she's very engaging to watch.The only negative is that the villain was not that amazing. He was good, but he could have been slightly better. He was better than the last villain, but not nearly as good as Phillip Seymour Hoffman in MI3. But it works for this movie.Overall, this is a fun, smart, and fantastic adrenaline ride. It's one of the best movies so far this year and I highly recommend it.

Good, tight plot, solid action sequences (although I think it does not quite match up, overall, to "Ghost Protocol") and the usual charming performance by Cruise and Co. makes it a worthwhile ride.With that said, its lofty promises are somewhat unfulfilled. The titular "Rogue Nation" is more of a rogue special-ops team. Which is fine, it is just a retread of ideas that have been done, and I expect will be done similarly in the upcoming 007 "Spectre" film. You've got well-funded, highly trained and very secret organization run by a fanatic. It's not the same as an actual nation-state going 'rogue' and ultimately, the handful of agents have inconsequential effect on the outcome... and thus the overall threat seems illusory in the end. Especially compared to, you know, actual nuclear damnation. And of course Ethan Hunt and the MI team have been disavowed, split up, and are themselves going rogue. Wait isn't that how it goes in like, *every* movie? Ghost protocol had the advantage of not delving much into the villain's motives and letting his threat speak for itself, whereas this one seems to *want* to explain the villain's motives, and it attempts to do so, and it focus on the villain quite a bit, but he never really becomes a full character. Right. So perhaps this is just what you'd expect, and what is interesting is that this time the consequences become much more personal, as instead of a plot threatening the world or, at least, very important people, the consequences are very personal.

Simon Pegg and Ferguson's eyes are the stars here and that is just fine. Its a solid story and has some nice action. Exactly what it should be, but is it more? Not really. Cruise gets credit for hanging in there all these years and pulling off roles like this, but its still just an action movie.

Man...talk about the little franchise that could. In the crowded landscape of the mid-tier action film, the Mission Impossible series has quietly built a name for itself by delivering not only absurd, mostly practical action sequences (bless your crazy ass lack of restraint, Tom Cruise) but a healthy dose of heart to its highly relatable cast of characters. "Groundbreaking," "Next Level" and "Genre-Redefining" are all things that won't be said about any of these movies, but "fun," "entertaining" and "surprisingly fresh" absolutely are.

The franchise has gradually refined its combination of jaw-dropping action set pieces and sleekly cool world of espionage into something that's approaching pop perfection. As for Cruise, he has always been a remarkable physical actor, and the Mission: Impossible franchise continues to offer an ideal showcase for his talents.

It dresses up a weakly-realized cartoon supervillain (who literally shoots one of his own henchman for no reason cuz he's mad I guess. he does that thing. that thing. in 2015) in grown-up political thriller clothes, and overloads the story with stuffy airs, at the expense of efficiency, tautness, and, ironically, believability. Disclaimer:� I am judging this movie almost exclusively off its predecessor, which I absolutely loved. So yes, this one fell a little short for me.� I became a big fan of MI when they rebooted the unfortunately short-lived TV series in the late 80's.� I'm a sucker for ensemble pieces, and MI is the pinnacle of that concept:� a group of people, each with a particular skill-set, joining together to overcome ridiculous odds and achieve a common goal (this is also why I loved The Avengers, Ocean's Eleven, even The Goonies).� IMF was a team, and they were all badass.� Hence, I was disappointed when they started making the MI films because, with the exception of the first 15 minutes of the first film,�there is never a team - it's just the superhuman Ethan Hunt running around and doing everything himself.� Then came "Ghost Protocol", and I was so happy... the team was back!� And they were badass!� I was hoping for more of the same with this film, and sadly, it did not deliver.� The same team is there (with the exception of Paula Patton, who is inexplicably absent and is never even mentioned in the movie... but there is another chick in this one, and these movies have a strict one-chick limit), but they aren't given the opportunity to do anything cool.� They just hang around and let Ethan do all the cool stuff.� For this reason, I was disappointed.� That being said, it's still a really fun action movie.� It's exactly the same formula as all the other films, but somehow it still works.� It's like a Bond film: the situations are ridiculous and most of it doesn't make a lick of sense, but you can still sit back and enjoy it for the fun ride that it is.� Tom Cruise may be a nutcase, but he's one hell of an action star.� The supporting cast is great too, particularly Simon Pegg, who gives the film both its heart and its humor.� It's a fun summer action flick and worth a trip to theater, but "Ghost Protocol" will continue to be the only film from this franchise to have a place on my shelf.

A somewhat less action-packed sequel, but that totally is a great and critical movie-flick.Mission Impossible is back, with Tom Cruise still hanging around with his great performance to action and acting. Rouge Nation starts pretty fast with a stunning opening-sequence and a beautiful first act that's touching, artistic and beautiful. Simon Pegg co-stars as the somewhat newcomer to the spy-genre and contributes in his own funny & entertaining way. The plot progresses in a less action-packed version, and it place more energy to dialogs and chemistry between characters rather than on action. It's one thing that might be boring for some, and awesome to others. For me was it a somewhat boring ride with all the dry dialogs and more talking than doing. But the dialogs are of course still very good even though that there are some classic "obvious reaction dialogs" and that I expected more action. The action that is present is on the other hand very intense and somewhat unique. Some of them stands out as a brand and original concept, meanwhile others are the same that we've already seen. Rouge Nation is a very stunning and, on my behalf, a critically acclaimed movie that got many things from strong actors to a well written story. The villain however, got no depth, and some of the minor characters are so non-existing due to lack of plot-details around them. Some of them are just there for a specific reason to enlighten the power of the film. Mission Impossible: Rouge Nation is still a great movie, even though I was deeply disappointed due to lack of action and a less interesting plot that made the dialogs a bit dry. The plot is still slightly unique, even though I expected more due to the trailers, but the humor is still what I was hoping for! So random and hilarious!It's obviously a disappointment from my point of view because the movie isn't that much more intense than the trailers, and it's not that rememberable neither. I expected a lot more, even though it really is a stunning and critically great action-flick with exquisite acting, a well written script and well visualized characters.Personal rating: 70/10Critical rating: 80/10

Rogue Nation is impossibly magnificent, a spellbinding cocktail of intrigue and jaw-dropping action sequences that hits Mariah Carey-level notes from minute one. Most top-flight film franchises flame out by the third rendezvous (Hello, Godfather). If Live Free or Die Hard was a passable two-plus hours of blow-up-stuff escapism, the fifth lap for detective John McLane was deplorably brutal. Dearest Bruce, it's time to retire the NYPD badge. Mission Impossible's fifth installment, though, bucks the trend and nails every frame the way Ghost Protocol did. At no point does Cruise as mind and ass-kicking IMF agent Ethan Hunt veer into washed up action star territory. He remains THE man. Even when the plot curve balls become calculable, they are just as hard to hit and just as mesmerizing when they unfold. Jeremy Renner, Ving Rhames, Rebecca Ferguson, Alec Baldwin and especially Simon Pegg are outstanding as supporting cast members. Still, it's Cruise who captains perhaps the most reliable ship in Hollywood. In a cinematic world overrun by second-rate sequels that offer nothing more than batting practice, Rogue Nation is, against all logic, a bleeping no hitter.

Rouge Nation has moments that clearly show off the raw film-making talent that went into it, but it does feel a bit smaller than its predecessor. As per the usual, the setpieces are what standout, and this movie has 3 or 4 that really nail it home. Unfortunately, while the ending has a great moment in it, it's scaled-down from the rest of the film, and the villain isn't particularly memorable. The primary actors do an incredible job fitting their roles, especially Ferguson as a female agent who hits on par with Tom Cruise. Rouge Nation is sleek and well-paced, makes great use of its elements, and even toys with some interesting narrative ideas.
Smartly crafted, adrenaline-fuelled fun.

Mission Impossible: Keep Building Up a Franchise While Adding An Artistic ToneIt's hard to make a good spy movie nowadays. It feels as though everything has practically been done already. With a franchise like Mission Impossible, which tries to top itself with every successive film, the audience's expectation bar is set even higher. However, what defines a regular moviemaker from an artist is that an artist always strives to go beyond. In that sense Christopher McQuarrie might have taken the first step to be considered an "auteuristic" director; of course we can't really define a director based on only one film, but his most recent outing: Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation certainly projects high hopes for his future. Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation tries to raise the stakes like no other M.I. film has done before. That's why the film starts with the Impossible Mission Force (IMF) being not only hunted down by a terrorist nation known as 'The Syndicate," but also being shut-down by its own government after the many protests of the handling of missions from the CIA chief Alan Hunley (Alec Baldwin). The IMF's top agent Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) goes rogue after IMF is shutdown because of the CIA's unwillingness to believe the existence of "The Syndicate." Ethan Hunt must go solo with the help of a few of disavowed IMF members including Benji (Simon Pegg), Brandt (Jeremy Renner), and Luther (Ving Rhames) to show the world the threat they keep denying.  But people go to M.I. movies in order to see extreme missions that are well.... impossible. The last outing had Ethan Hunt climb the tallest tower in the world. To top that (pun intended) there are two stunning scenes in Rogue Nation; one near the beginning of the film has Hunt clinging to a plane's wing as it takes off (a stunt that Tom Cruise pulled off on his own); and the other has Hunt hold his breath under water for three whole minutes to change a memory stick in an enormous cooling cylinder with an incredibly strong current. So this film does its job and tops the other great M.I. stunts seen in M.I. 3 and M.I. Ghost Protocol. But that's not what surprised me. What really surprised me was the incredible balance that director McQuarrie was able to achieve. He held off the action sequences long enough so that they didn't burn out quickly, something that other action films pour in excess and make us lose interest and admiration in the stunts and choreography. The comedy also was toned down a bit from the last film. Simon Pegg's comic relief is more accurate due to less quantity and more quality. I certainly was fearing that the franchise and their comedic take might have taken a wrong turn and move towards the cheesy Fast and Furious style, but McQuarrie was able to stabilize that. The director also was able to make the film smart. What I mean by that is that the decisions taken by the agents aren't the predictable sort you get in your typical movies; the characters actually looked as though they were highly trained and their quick thinking and innovation catch the audience off-guard and it certainly surprises us and reminds us of why we enjoy spy movies in the first place. Finally there was a round of hommages that McQuarrie features throughout his film. Ranging from a thrilling opera sequence similar to that of Alfred Hitchcock's The Man Who Knew Too Much, to a play with names and character arcs paying tribute to Casablanca in very subtle ways. As for acting Tom Cruise more than holds his own. His intense performance shows us that he is truly an eternal movie star who still has it in him to keep up with us. Simon Pegg and Jeremy Renner are both solid as well, but the real revelation here was Rebecca Ferguson. Rebecca Ferguson plays Ilsa Faust whose allegiance the characters and audience are always doubting (is she a double agent? Triple agent?) It's hard to act your character acting under pressure, and Ferguson makes it look so easy! Not only that, but she manages to keep you guessing where her loyalties truly lie until McQuarrie finally deems it opportune to let you know. Such an actor is any director's dream. I also enjoyed how she wasn't at all used as a romantic interest at any point; she was equally as important and significant as Ethan or Benji's characters, something that is sadly not common with female roles. So in the end not only are there various auteur brush-strokes throughout this movie, but you also see McQuarrie raise a franchise's already high level and we enjoy a set of incredibly great performances. Indeed it is an extremely enjoyable film. It's just a bit sad (or not) that you stop believing that any impossible missions exist.

Rogue Nation continued on the fast paced and action packed world of the Mission Impossible franchise. Tom Cruise is his usual stunt loving self, and knowing that he actually hooked himself onto the side of the plane as it took off was a great thing to watch. Other actors would have shied away from such a daunting task but he seems to thrive on the danger. Simon Pegg brings his usual comical character back into the game and puts it alongside the returning characters of Ving Rhames, and Jeremy Renner to get some wonderful scenes. Of course a Mission Impossible film would not be the same without a couple of tense and worried moments thrown in, and this does not disappoint. There is one scene specifically which will have you holding your breath hoping for it all to pan out well. I think that they keep managing to pull a very good film out of the bag, despite the initial worries I have when they announce that they are making another one. If they keep making them like this then I say long may they continue.

Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation is the fifth instalment in the long running Mission: Impossible franchise and just when you thought they couldn't get any better Tom Cruise returns to prove that he is still one of the best action stars and that this franchise is still one of best in the action genre. But he couldn't do it alone, with the aid of an incredibly strong and entertaining supporting cast, very likeable characters and an entertaining plot, this is definitely a must see in the spy thriller genre. When it comes to high octane action set pieces, no-one does it better than Mission Impossible. The absolutely extreme stunts and high speed chases return in full force and take the franchise to new 'heights' and 'depths' (literally) and with Ethan Hunt at the helm, the IMF have a new covert operation on their hands. The stunts and action set pieces in this film are awesome to watch you have your fair share of fast paced shootouts and chases and also your more low-key dangerous stunts, all of which were gripping, intense and had you on the edge of your seat. The fact that realism is mostly out of the question when dealing with these stunts really helps to up the stakes and gives the writers and director more creative freedom to wow us in as many ways as possible. The team from Ghost Protocol has returned in this film and i think it was a great thing to keep Simon Pegg, Jeremy Renner, and Ving Rhames together in this film because their chemistry comes through so well in the film and you really get behind these guys. Their characters are always funny when they need to be and badass when required making for some fun, humorous moments that keep the mood very light amidst all of the intense action scenes. The villain of the film i thought was very strong also, 'they' weren't a moustache twirling evil mastermind, they actually had some interesting and mysterious qualities that kept me more engaged in the film. The performances were all incredible and convincing, even from newcomer Rebecca Ferguson as Isla Faust who adds a lot to the film in terms of stunts and especially in terms of plot. Speaking of the plot, i thought it definitely was a very well thought out plot with a lot of pieces and hints throughout that all come together in the finale. It seems to have been very intricately planned out and isn't just one of your throwaway stop the bad guy plots. There are a few organisations and characters that you have to keep track of in order to completely follow where the story is going. And i have to admit, the strength and focus on having this very well thought out story caught me off guard a few times especially towards the beginning and later on towards the end. I went in half expecting to see some mindless action and fun with some form of easy to follow story that tied the whole film together, but i realised fairly early on that it was going to need some concentration. Once i managed to understand what was going on and who exactly the multiple parties going at each other were it all began to make sense and was pretty interesting and entertaining. I am not saying you can't go into this film and watch it just for the fun and action but just be warned that during the story centred scenes and the resolution at the end you will be very lost and maybe even bored. But it's tough to knock this down too much for anything story related as it accomplishes everything a Mission: Impossible film sets out to do; great action and stunts, characters you know and love and a plot to tie it all together. If you are a fan of the franchise, no doubt you have already seen it, but incase you had any doubts, this is definitely a good, fun time at the theatres. - 8/10P.S, I have to say i am incredibly impressed with the action spy thriller genre this year, we have had 'Kingsman: The Secret Service', 'The Man from U.N.C.L.E', now this and 'Spectre' later in the year, all very different and all very great (Spectre excluded).

Believe it or not, until now I have never seen a Mission Impossible film. While I love action films, the premise just never appealed to me, but when I heard Christopher McQuarrie would be Directing this latest one, I had to see it. McQuarrie, the brains behind Persons Unknown, always tells imaginative stories, that while aren't that believable, are still extremely entertaining. In the fifth installment of Mission Impossible, the franchise is anything but stale as it is every bit as fast paced and extreme as I thought. I was expecting the action and for Tom Cruise to play his usually arrogant self, but what I wasn't expect was just how intense and in depth the story was. There is also the villain to consider, who was so much better than I hoped he'd be. I had always thought of Mission Impossible as sort of a mix between Get Smart and James Bond, and was presently surprised to learn that I was way off base. Rogue Nation is actually a very clever story, that isn't is as comical or as over the top with espionage as I thought it would be. In fact, the only thing that really was what I expected was Tom Cruise. While he's not my favorite actor, he's not a bad one either, I just never liked the fact that every character he plays is just so full of themselves. No matter the situation, Ethan Hunt was always so sure he had all the answers and knew exactly what to do, and even when he was wrong it didn't deter him from getting right back into it. Rogue Nation taught me a lesson I never seem to get, in that you really can't judge a book by it's cover. Certain stories may appear to be one thing, but you can never know for sure unless you sit down and watch them.

After nearly two decades of globetrotting and thwarting the malignant plans of terrorist organizations as a member of the IMF, Tom Cruise reprises his role as special agent Ethan Hunt in 'Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation.' In his fifth case, Hunt and his rag-tag teammates (including Jeremy Renner, Simon Pegg and Ving Rhames) are thrown a curveball when the IMF is disbanded, making their task of hunting down the infamous Syndicate rogue nation of terrorists that much harder. Along their travels, which take them to exotic locales from Austria to Morocco, Hunt and co cross paths with Ilsa Faust (Rebecca Ferguson), a beautiful MI6 agent who is doubling as a member of the Syndicate. As you might imagine, there are all sorts of action-packed sequences, witty dialogue and comic relief (mostly at the expense of Pegg) and a killer soundtrack that help propel 'Rogue Nation' along.At the center of 'Rogue Nation' is a plot that has many different layers, with each one being peeled back to unearth another as the core team delves deeper into the plans of the Syndicate. There is a combination of cutting-edge technology, high-speed chases through narrow streets and crazy stunts - particularly the opening scene with the takeoff and the daredevil dive into the waterlogged security safe. In this sense, there are few aspects of the film that disappoint.It may not be the most groundbreaking spy-driven action drama, but 'Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation' delivers exactly what is expected of it - nothing more, nothing less.

I did enjoy this film, but not as much as I hoped I would. The opening and last 20 odd minutes are the most entertaining. It's got some good laugh, some good performances and a few memorable scenes, but mostly it's a very complicated, very clich�d and very unbelievable series of events and encounters. The film makes the same mistake that the latest Fast & Furious film makes, and forgets that if our lead characters are undamageable/unkillable, then there's no reason to feel any tension when they're put in life-threatening situations. We need our heroes to be under threat, but when they're drowned, beaten up or in horrific car accidents and come out with barely a scratch on them, it feels as though the filmmakers don't really care about their mortality. And if they don't care, why should the audience? The actions scenes themselves are pretty exciting, and showcase some fairly impressive stunts, but when a car shoots into the air and rolls backwards at insane speed and the characters can emerge unscathed and continue their chase largely unhindered, it just feels like the movie is on a desperate quest to get onto the next scene as fast as possible without properly concluding the one its currently in. Another issue is the editing of the fights scenes. It's very awkward and choppy, but despite this it's glaringly obvious where the humans stop and the computer effects begin, making the hand to hand combat appear very disjointed and unnatural. The main objective, which should have earth-shattering consequences, is wrapped up with little fanfare, the characters are forced into scenes of overlong exposition in order to explain the storyline, and it's just very lacking in suspense. We've seen this kind of film enough times to predict what's going to happen to the characters and the plot. It's not terrible, just very underwhelming, and not one I'll be seeking out when it's released on DVD.

Yeah, it should be called Mission Possible! This is the fifth time they are telling that something is "impossible" and then proceed to do exactly that. Has by any chance the meaning of "impossible" changed in the meantime. Some of you may still be scratching your heads now as to what I am talking about! It is about the fifth installment of the hugely popular Mission Impossible series. Banking on the super stardom of Tom Cruise, the series has always been a cash cow, while providing some high-octane action, and an American James Bond in Ethan Hunt.The fifth installment, titled Rogue Nation, takes off from where the previous one ended, and follows Ethan Hunt as he, along with his IMF (Impossible Missions Force) attempt to bring down The Syndicate, a mysterious international criminal organisation. Unfortunately, IMF has officially been dismantled and Hunt is an American fugitive..The movie, offers nothing new, and has the typical ingredients of a spy thriller - a female double agent, a cold villain, and some supporting characters thrown here and there. The story line is vague and inconsistent, and an inherent weakness in scripting is apparent. At times, the scenes are monotonous and reminiscent of previous movies of the franchise. Director Chrisopher McQuarrie (of The Tourist fame) steers clear of any experimentation and sticks to the basics. And that is not essentially a bad thing. The crisp editing and excellent cinematography make up for the writing flaws and give us some brilliant action sequences and moments of thrill.The performances are decent, with the exception of Rebecca Ferguson, as the MI6 double agent, Elsa Faust, who shines through with a compelling performance. She is beautiful, and puts in some spice to the movie. But who am I kidding here :P ! Mission Impossible, was, is and always will be a Tom Cruise film. He is 52, and it shows on his face. But he has lost none of his charm or star power. In fact, that is what powers this film through its discrepancies!Overall, MI: Rogue Nation, is all that it is supposed to be, a perfect summer blockbuster. It thoroughly entertains you and is far better than some other sequels released this year (read: Jurassic World and Terminator: Genisys). Watch this movie if you want to have some brainless fun and entertainment.

Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation is another solid example that some franchises have the amazing ability to remain relevant to different audiences and to get better with every new installment. While the fifth delivery of the Mission Impossible series does not quite match the level of Ghost Protocol from 2011 it still remains a top 2015 summer blockbuster entertainment. Slick, action-packed, with the typical dose of impossible stunts and spiced up with additional level of good humor, Rogue Nation is a summer thrill ride that also offers a storyline and content which would please the more pretentious spy/mystery movie fans.When the IMF team is disbanded and Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) is declared wanted, it all seems that the world would be taken by a secret organization known as The Syndicate. Left with nothing, chased by everyone, Ethan and his ex-team have limited time to prove that the IMF should not have been disbanded and that The Syndicate exists. Christopher MacQuarrie exploits almost the same concept which made Ghost Protocol the best Mission Impossible delivery. Fast-paced story that is actually pretty well built with not obvious plot holes (if you try to delve deeper, you would actually find some), a refreshing amount of good humor provided by Simon Pegg in duet with Tom Cruise, slick and thrilling action sequences and above all the impressively effective Tom Cruise. It is true that Rogue Nation falls just short from being as thrilling and breath-taking as Ghost Protocol, but probably this is also due to the settings chosen for some of the action sequences. As many are probably expecting the biggest asset of Mission Impossible is Tom Cruise. It is amazing how at 52 he still seems pretty credible as Special Agent Ethan Hunt. Cruise's action charisma is working flawlessly to a level that he has become one of the very few Hollywood actors around whom a whole franchise is built. What is more amazing is that this franchise spans over a huge period of 19 years in which Cruise has never lost its shape. In conclusion, Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation is another most welcome addition to the very successful spy franchise which may not reach the outstanding level of its predecessor Ghost Protocol but still it provides formidable summer entertainment and leaves the fans expecting the next delivery from the franchise. A recommended 132-minute entertainment!
