There is no way in the world that I could ever begin to explain the plot of Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation and not make it sound like the last ten spy movies that you saw. That's probably because the plot of this movie doesn't really matter anyway, it's beside the point. Believe it or not, that's kind of a compliment. I have come to realize that this is the method that makes this series work. Take a bland spy plot about All-Star International Team of Professional Bad Guys armed the latest technological whozee-whatzit trying to bring down nations with a bullet and a keystroke, then plug in some highly entertaining well-planned, well thought-out action sequences that hold our attention. It's a formula that seems to work.Rogue Nation is the fourth sequel in a series that I have come to have a lot of affection for. It is a product that offers a certain seal of approval, especially when it's being produced by Hollywood's current whiz-kid J.J. Abrams. A few years ago, Abrams climbed on board this flawed, clunky series with the supremely underrated Mission: Impossible III and did something amazing - he made it fun. While James Bond and Jason Bourne steered toward grungy, real-world stuff, The Mission: Impossible pictures swim comfortably in the kinds of fun, inoffensive waters that the Roger Moore-era Bond pictures did.The plot - let's just get it out of the way - involves Ethan (Tom Cruise) and the IMF team hunting down evidence of the All-Star International Team of Professional Bad Guys who are called The Syndicate (I think my name is better) who want to infiltrate the top governments of the world and bring them down by assassinating their key leaders. Meanwhile the CIA (led by Alec Balwin, playing the stuff-shirt role for all its worth) wants to disband the IMF due to its repeated instances of collateral damage and for its inability to uncover proof of The Syndicate. Got all that? Good. Let's move on.The Syndicate is pretty indistinguishable from Hydra or S.P.E.C.T.R.E. or The Galactic Empire, only you can't easily spot them and their uniforms aren't as interesting. Their chief assassin is a quiet, creepy little man called Solomon (Sean Harris) whose odd face and silent demeanor gets under your skin. He's really an effective bad guy.What is special about this series, and this movie in particular is Tom Cruise. While his drama films repeatedly fall flat, he's made himself a really effective action star. As Ethan Hunt, he spends nearly the entire film performing stunts that should either put him in traction or in a cemetery. In that way he's a little like Indiana Jones. He gets hurt, a lot. When he crashes through a window or gets punched in the ribs by a Russian the size of a gorilla, you feel the crunch. At one point is he captured by Syndicate agents and beaten by a Russian called "The Bone Doctor." Later he jumps into a centrifuge full of water with no air tank. Then he gets into a long car/motorcycle chase down the busy streets of Morocco, and gets into an accident that by all laws of physics should have gotten him killed. Plus, you care about him. There are moments when he genuinely looks scared. How many action heroes do that?But the single best action scene in the movie takes place in The Vienna Opera House where Ethan must deal with two assassins at once, climbing around on the catwalks during a performance of Puccini's "Turandot," and battling a six-foot German killing machine. The scene works because of the way it is orchestrated with the music, and the way that the action is relatively quiet, as if the combatants are being respectful to the performers on stage. Having been inundated with so many bad action movies, I figured that it would end with a body falling on stage but, you know what, it didn't. This is a movie full of nice surprises.Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation is directed by Christopher McQuarrie, who is most famous for his Oscar Winning (and in my opinion overrated) screenplay to The Usual Suspects some 20 years ago. Here he shows a sure hand, letting the action scenes move on just a little longer then we might expect. They're so good that we want them to go on. The music plays such an integral part in this film. There is a beautifully directed moment when Cruise and his female counterpart are at gunpoint in an outdoor cafe in Vienna; the music drop out as the camera pushes in on their faces. They eye each other, silently working out a plan without words. Then Puccini's opera swells on the soundtrack as the action kicks into gear. To my knowledge, I haven't seen this kind of approach in an American action film; that's the kind of thing I usually see in Italian or Japanese pictures. If the filmmakers must steal, at least they're stealing from good sources.That's what you notice, the technique, not the plotting. The plot is small enough that it gets out of the actor's way. We care about the characters, especially Ben Dunn, played wonderfully by Simon Pegg. He has such a substantial role in this movie that it almost becomes a buddy movie. He could have been just a comic foil, but his connection with Hunt is so tight that we feel that they genuinely care for one another. The same goes for Swedish actress Rebecca Ferguson as the wonderfully named Ilsa Faust, a Syndicate operative whose loyalties are always in question. She has an unpredictable relationship with Hunt that moves back and forth.On the whole, this movie is just plain fun. Is it preposterous? Yes. Is it too long? Yes. But you don't mind because the movie gets the job done. It's a step above the usual fare of this type. You remember the action. You remember the characters. But you don't care anything about the plot. It's a fun ride, better than the average, but it accomplishes it's mission. That's all we ask.

Although I've never seen a single episode of the 1960s television show and didn't much care for the first film, I've grown to be a big fan of the Mission Impossible franchise. The stories are interesting, the characters are likable, the villains are easy to hate, and it has some the most entertaining action sequences in any film series. And yes, Tom Cruise still runs like no one else in the business.We're now five films in and this franchise is still alive and kicking. Although "Ghost Protocol" may still be the best installment, "Rouge Nation" is a strong second. This time Ethan Hunt (Cruise) and friends of the IMF are out to track down and prove the existence of an international criminal/terrorist organization known as the Syndicate. And in typical spy movie fashion, the CIA doesn't approve of the IMF's tactics, there's a double agent whose true motives are unclear, there could be a traitor in the group, and there's tension filled bomb countdowns. That all may sound painfully clich�d, they're all done in ways that feel stylish, creative and fresh.I'm an unapologetic Tom Cruise fan. He's one of the last remaining action stars left and I really appreciate all the effort he puts into these movies. The returning supporting cast are also as good as ever. Simon Pegg is still one of the best comic relief actors working today, Jeremy Renner is his usual stellar self, and Ving Rhames is Ving Rhames and that's all he needs to be. The stand-out new addition is Rebecca Ferguson. I didn't expect much from her going in, but I wouldn't be surprised if we see her in a superhero franchise down the road. She's what Black Widow should have been in the Avengers films.M.I.5 is another solid entry in the series and I highly recommend it. It may never reach the masterpiece levels of action and ferocity as a "Mad Max: Fury Road", but it'll be one of the more flat-out fun times you'll have this year.

Nothing more and nothing less.

Back in 2005, and with his franchise in creative hiatus, Tom Cruise made the very wise decision to recruit J.J. Abrams to revitalize his ailing Mission: Impossible films and the series hasn't looked back since. With 2006s Mission: Impossible 3, 2011s Mission: Impossible-Ghost Protocol and now with 2015s Mission: Impossible-Rogue Nation, Cruise can stand toe-to-toe with the closest franchise that features exotic locales, espionage, gadgets, villainy and an over-the-top super agent. While that certain series has gone to the gritty side of things, the Mission: Impossible films have stayed true to the Cold War intrigue, fun and adventure that the spy genre cut its teeth in. Balancing this right amount of fun, suspense, mystery and action, writer/director (and first timer to the franchise) Christopher McQuarrie had quite the shoes to fill. Instead of putting his own fingerprints on the franchise too aggressively, McQuarrie has instead created a film that is, at times, one big homage to the ones before (even including shout outs to that other franchise). There are traces of the paranoid head games from Brian De Palma, the over-the-top action from John Woo, that kinetic energy from Abrams and then the fun and honest sense of adventure from Brad Bird. It all adds up to a spy film that is well balanced, with some fine set pieces and a great awareness for character. Ten years on from when the franchise was at it's lowest, 2015s Mission: Impossible-Rogue Nation proves that this is a series worth keeping an eye out for-should you choose to accept it.

Dud Dud Dud...Dud Dud DudMission Impossible Rogue Nation was a fun movie, it provided a great amount of comedy that didn't take away from the film and actually had some good twists and turns. But.....it lacked the direction needed to make it a true classic.This movie gave me a headache trying to keep up with its stories. Instead of having a fun spy movie MIRN gave me too many undeaded plots to keep up with. Just as I adjusted to one story it would switch to a totally unneeded other story that made it near impossible to follow and even harder for me to get into.The story at first seems innocent and makes sense, but when you look back at it you really start to see the holes in the story. So much of the plot was manipulated in multiple ways just to show action. The bike chase in Morocco is a perfect example, Benji had an extra copy of the drive the whole time so why did Ethan have to risk his life in a high speed chase to collect something they already had. Another example of this was the final battle between Ethan and William. Sure Ethan just killed multiple of your men but he and he alone also holds the 50 million dollars needed to put your plan in motion. So why would you attempt to kill him? The plot just doesn't add up to create a realistic movie.In the end Mission Impossible Rouge Nation is a fun action filled adventure that is worth checking out. But misses the simple elements to get higher in my opinion than a 3/5

Normally when you get to the 5th film of a franchise, there's a massive drop in the quality. Not for this franchise. This just keeps on getting better and better. I didn't think it would get better than Ghost Protocol, but Rogue Nation might be my favorite Mission Impossible film till date.Tom Cruise is one of the biggest movie star we've ever had. And at the age of 53, he still is a legit action star. Some of the stunts he does in this film will leave you in awe. The plane scene is the first 5 minutes, and it isn't even the most exciting one. There's an underwater scene, an Opera house sequence, a bike chase scene, and each one ups the tempo from the previous one. Tom Cruise loves playing Ethan Hunt, and people may not like to agree but Hunt is right there with Bond and Bourne.Simon Pegg, you don't realize how good of an actor he is unless you see him acting. He can bring the laughter to a movie like this without making it cheesy or slapstick. He is fantastic in this film.Jeremy Renner gets to do a bit more this time, and he does a great job in the supporting role. He has some great moments with Alec Baldwin who surprisingly is really good in this film. Ving Rhames also shows up for few scenes and he just takes over the scene when he's on.We expect Tom Cruise to be badass and Simon Pegg to be funny, but the real surprise package here is Rebecca Ferguson. She's a total revelation. Her character Ilsa Faust is right up there with Imperator Furiosa as a badass female character. She brought an extra layer to this film and managed to create that suspense element throughout. We should be seeing a lot of her in the future films.Sean Harris as the villain in this film is one of the best part of the film. He may not match Hunt's strength, but he's always one step ahead of him. Very Riddler-ish, he was fantastic. Though I would've liked to know more about the Syndicate. I don't have any negatives about this film. Mad Max still has the best action sequences, but this is by far the best action film of the year.Credits to Christopher McQuarrie who had a huge task to follow up Brad Bird and he did it brilliantly.

This is the 5th Mission: Impossible film. Tom Cruise is now in his 50s! In Mission: Impossible 5 the IMF (Impossible Mission Force) is deemed unnecessary by the U.S. government and is disbanded and some of the agents are moved into the CIA. Meanwhile, the Syndicate, a sort of evil version of the IMF announces it's presence to Ethan Hunt (Cruise). Hunt must now hunt down and stop the Syndicate without the resources of the IMF and as a fugitive from the U.S. government.Things I Liked:The Cast. The entire cast of this film is strong, but highest props go to Rebecca Ferguson who comes in and holds her own as a badass. She takes the stage and steals the scenes and does it in a way that is never about being a badass female, she is just a badass and he gender never for a moment defines that fact. But the entire cast delivers. Tom Cruise, Simon Pegg, Jeremy Renner, Ving Rahmes, Alec Baldwin, and Sean Harris as the villain, all have their moment and each one stands out at one time or another.The Action. This is an action film. And oh man does it deliver. The stunt work is great, the fights are interesting and exciting, the chase scenes are edge of your seat excitement, there are explosions, gun shots, and moments that remind you that Tom Cruise is truly a one of a kind action star. The film is exciting and it manages to do things that push the boundries where you think the stunt is almost impossible but you still believe that Hunt can do it. Awesome!The plot. This film has a better and more interesting plot than the previous few Mission: Impossible films. The film does a lot more espionage and that was what I really enjoyed about the first one was the spy work, the double crosses, the figuring out of the puzzle. This movie does that but also has moments where the actions is high. It's a really intriguing mental battle between Hunt and the Syndicate and both trying to be a step ahead of the other.Things I Didn't Like:Too Many Twists. The movie is an act too long, there are one too many obstacles for the character to navigate. The movies is just a little long and you feel like moments where they have to run through problems are a bit unnecessary. This is a seriously nitpicky thing because there wasn't a lot I didn't like with this film.Overall. Overall this film is awesome. The cast is strong, the action is high, the plot is interesting. Everything works really well and there are moments where the movie feels a bit like there are too many obstacles but by the end you are just excited about what you saw. This has a been a summer for exciting action films and this one is right up there with the best of them.

Ethan Hunt is back to his old spying antics, delivering everything that fans of the franchise have come to expect. As a rogue agent disowned by his own government, he must confront the looming threat of 'The Syndicate', an elusive but powerful 'rogue nation' of ex-intelligence agents. Along the way, Hunt must attempt to distinguish friend from foe in a maze of shifting allegiances.Sound familiar? It probably is. While 'agent goes rogue' and 'mysterious global organisation' are well-trodden tropes of the spy genre (most Bond films for a start!), the director and co-writer Christopher McQuarrie manages to do it in a way that still feels fresh and exciting.Rogue Nation has all the things that a franchise in its fifth outing needs: self-awareness, original characters and a fresh story. Most impressive about this picture are the action set-pieces, of which the Opera sequence is surely the most lauded, and rightly so. A close second comes in the first five minutes. The film opens 'in medias res' (in the midst of the action) to what is surely the most talked about scene in the run up to the film's release - Tom Cruise hanging off the side of a plane (for reals!).I would have liked the obligatory 'heist' section to have been fleshed out a little. As Simon Pegg's character ironically points out - 'Mission: Impossible' is more like 'Mission: Very Difficult', and not even. After ten minutes of action they had retrieved the MacGuffin and it was on to the next obstacle.While many have praised the film for giving its only female character an equal footing to the series' protagonist, there were too many leering camera shots and inexplicably revealing, non-functional, outfits in order for me to be completely satisfied with the film's gender politics.If you go into this film expecting your disposable action fare, you may be pleasantly surprised. But while this entry into the franchise certainly delivers on thrills, don't go expecting any real world relevance or lasting message; just sit back and have fun.

Rogue Nation had a lot to live up to, being the follow-up to the immensely successful and acclaimed Ghost Protocol (2011). I myself was unsure whether any future MI movie could top the relentless action, fast-paced story, and globe-trotting endeavors present in MI4, but I'll be damned if this isn't the best installment of the franchise yet. Rogue Nation manages to provide enough substantial plot and jaw-dropping stunts to top its predecessors, even managing to become the first Mission film to flesh out a solid villain.

Tom Cruise gets younger every year with his jaw-dropping stunts but Simon Pegg really steals the show here. Pacing feels off at times between the action and the espionage buildup but the brilliantly directed set-pieces (three in particular) more than make up for it. The franchise is definitely not showing any fatigue.

Let me start by saying that Rogue Nation has the best ensemble out of the entire series, with everyone bringing something to the table. Cruise brings charm and likability to a character that, by this deep into a series, could be easily worn-out and tiresome. Everyone else fills their roles exactly how you would want them to, with more attention being put on Simon Pegg's Benji this time around, although the true breakout star was Rebecca Ferguson, proving that not all damsels are in distress (for the most part). The movie delivers with brilliantly crafted action sequences, locations and sets that make you feel like you're really part of an adventure, and a solid enough story to keep you interested throughout with an occasional laugh on the way. If you choose to accept it... Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation is the best in the series so far.

Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation (2015) - After dwindling successive entries, it seemed as if the only thing keeping this spy franchise alive was the sheer will of Tom Cruise alone... You know, Scientology powers. Now that sheer will is converted into quality film-making with the likes of Brad Bird (The Incredibles) injecting life into the otherwise stale franchise in the fourth instalment "Ghost Protocol". In this new, fifth instalment, that streak of success continues in stride with Christopher McQuarrie (Jack Reacher) at the helm. This movie is solid from start to finish thanks in large part to an understanding of what made the last movie work so well. Boasting a strong, well rounded cast of characters with supporting roles that rival the lead in charisma; the highlight being Simon Pegg, who acts as the brains and comedic relief throughout. Then there's the inclusion of these huge over the top, action set pieces, perfected by practical sets and stunt work, adding a visceral edge to these movies that most modern action fair is missing. This is thanks in large part to a committed performance from Cruise, who earns his place as a veteran in this genre. Most of "Rogue Nation's" strengths are the same as its predecessor and shockingly it even manages to improve in some areas by adding a genuinely interesting villain into the mix which "Ghost Protocol" sorely lacked. Unfortunately, "Rogue Nation" also shares some of the last film's weaknesses too, most notably a bloated running-time. These movies would really benefit from a lean 110 minutes as opposed to the 140 this is sitting at. Odd pacing issues and too many convoluted sub-plots became a bit overwhelming, by the time the third act rolls around it's hard to tell where the climax is, as the film feels like a series of highs from the half way point forward. With all of that said, I really enjoyed this film and embraced it's flaws. These new "Mission Impossible" movies are great in their intelligence while also never taking themselves too seriously. There's a back-handed cheekiness that I really appreciate, so as long as Mr.Cruise is willing to keep this ball rolling, I'm on board. If action is what you crave this summer, look no further than this "Mission", should you choose to accept it.GRADE: A-

There is a chance that Mission: Impossible might be my favorite film franchise, because I believe they have maintained a consistency of quality that is unmatched by any other. Needless to say, I was quite excited to head to the theater for the fifth chapter in the series. I like that they made some references back to the previous film in order to maintain continuity, but they didn't really have a storyline that carried over. This allows both loyal fans and newcomers to enjoy the ride. And that's what these films have become, a wild ride of action and excitement. In Rogue Nation we find the IMF coming under fire, and Ethan Hunt is (once again) forced to work without the full support of his government to try and bring down the Syndicate, which is your typical evil spy agency. Tom Cruise remains a solid lead in this movie and continues to impress with stunts that are absolutely amazing. Simon Pegg is the perfect comic relief, but he also has added some depth to the character of Benji which makes him someone we can laugh at and respect at the same time. Jeremy Renner doesn't get much action, which is unfortunate, but his interactions with Alec Baldwin are a treat. The real find in this movie is the lovely Rebecca Ferguson. Her portrayal of Ilsa is excellent because she has some emotional moments that make her more than just a typical "Bond girl."The story felt a little messy at times, and didn't work quite as well as a couple of the other films in the franchise. I got annoyed by the fluctuating loyalty of a certain character, which almost became as messy as the Mac debacle in Kingdom of the Crystal Skull. I also must admit that there is a twist in one scene that I saw coming early on, which I think was supposed to fool me, but knowing the truth didn't hurt the moment. But let's be real here, the Mission: Impossible movies aren't even supposed to be about the plot any more, are they? It seems that the action is what is bringing in the audience more than the story. So, rest assured these action sequences are amazing. The famous scene of Tom Cruise hanging on an airplane is actually in a pre-credit sequence that doesn't really tie into the main plot, but things don't really go down from there. The set piece that I found most impressive was the motorcycle chase which was high-octane and really kept my heart thumping. There was also an extended underwater stunt which had me holding my breath as if I was right there with Ethan Hunt. Without question, this is a great action film, and one that I will gladly add to my Mission: Impossible collection. However, it didn't have quite as much of the magic in its plot construction (with mystery and intrigue) that have been the highlight of the series for me. But if you're looking for a summer action movie where you can just sit down, have fun, and gobble down some popcorn, then Rogue Nation is perfect for you.

'Rogue Nation', the fifth entry in the indubitably successful series is a rousing affair replete with sleek production values, one-liner-a-minute gags, gravity-defying practical stunts and a cool ooze of sex appeal that allows for maximum suspension of disbelief. Action stalwart and franchise front man Tom Cruise has no plans of slowing down with moves that would make most millennial age men truly envious. This film makes evident that he, along with returning cast members Simon Pegg, Ving Rhames and Jeremy Renner are still having a blast with a re-invigorated inspiration that runs through this movie's veins ever since the JJ Abrams directed MI3. Some stellar sequences abound including a taut, acrobatic and wonderfully mounted backstage shootout at an opera in Vienna as well as the riveting plane takeoff opener. Longtime fans expecting something truly new and game changing or even life affirming won't come away with much but for those who can manage their expectations well and know what this franchise is when its functioning at optimum levels should undoubtedly see this in all its big screen glory. Also, newcomer Rebecca Ferguson as a very compromised ex-MI6 British agent is a welcome addition and the scenes featuring her and Cruise are definite standouts in a movie bursting with style and visual panache. Enjoy!

I think the fifth Mission Impossible cut many fans short of the megahit that was expected. The movie succeeds in selling itself by promoting the fact that Tom Cruise does all his own stunts, but I feel that they had to do this because the film has no more than three quality action sequences and only one of them I would call original. It starts off a mess, with Tom Cruise making a unintelligible Hollywood entry and then the opening credits roll right before a major action scene finishes - cutting it off at the climax and never concluding it. This is probably because a very similar airplane scene was already done in FAST 7. The motorcycle chase scene also has been done more than enough times before. The only thing I can honestly remember from MI2 is lots of motorcycles. With the of exception the great underwater identification data swap scene, (which even felt familiar in its style of execution) the rest of the film's adrenaline comes from shootouts and hand-to-hand combat sequences mixed with intelligent spy twists. I was shocked at how anti-climactic the ending was. It's something that one would expect to see happen at the end of an OCEANS 11 movie. I've always found Simon Pegg to be the perfect comic relief for these movies, but even he didn't seem to be as funny this time around. MI 4, 3 & 1 are ranked amongst my top favorite action movies of all time. This one lands itself in the unfortunate spot right above MI2, which places it second from last in the series.

Going Rogue works exceedingly well for this nearly 20-year-old franchise, which makes it its Mission to entertain audiences with a worthy, bombastic, stunt-filled and action-packed follow-up to series high point Ghost Protocol. Just don't think about the spycraft too much or you might self-destruct. Please understand that the story only exists to set in motion an incendiary succession of set pieces, more bombastic and faint making than the last. Granted, the flick fails to include as much cheeky humor and top-notch plot points as the Impossible-to-beat 4th go-round. Though Rogue Nation never reaches its predecessor's nearly-perfectly rounded heights, however, the human and vehicular pyrotechnics make it a hugely enjoyable piece of popcorn. In this PG-13-rated actioner, Ethan (Cruise) and team (Renner, Simon Pegg, Ving Rhames) battle CIA bureaucracy and take on their most impossible mission yet, eradicating the Syndicate - an International rogue organization as highly skilled as they are, committed to destroying the IMF. Christopher McQuarrie (Jack Reacher) might possess the skill set for staging breakneck action of Ghost Protocol director Brad Bird (Tomorrowland), but the screenwriter of The Usual Suspects and Edge of Tomorrow knows just not to get in the way. Plus, his textured back-and-forths give us some engrossing one-on-one moments between some key characters - something we don't usually see from the IMF. Brilliantly leading the charge as always is Tom Cruise, a man so ridiculously great at his job that he makes the Impossible seem like child's play. He's been selling through weapons-grade fisticuffs and espionage for almost two decades now and makes it look more effortless with every passing flick. Someway somehow, he almost gets bested by an upstart. Rebecca Ferguson comes in out of nowhere and becomes a full-fledged star by the time the end credits roll. Simon Pegg adds some much-needed levity to the goings-on while Alec Baldwin provides a fascinating dynamic as a hard-nosed CIA suit who puts the always-spot-on Jeremy Renner through the paces.Bottom line: It Takes an Ovation of Millions

Straight off the bat Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation is humorous and action-packed, which leaves the audience wanting more. This film is full of amazing stunts straight from the very first scene, which are certainly very cool. The plot itself was very intricate and it keeps the audience on their toes, but also on the edge of their seats. There are always questions to be asked about what will happen next, and more importantly: who can be trusted? This can be a good thing, however at times I found myself a little too confused. The plot thickens as the film progresses, so pay attention or you may miss something. Tom Cruise's performance is very convincing as he plays a secret agent who is a member of the IMF. Simon Pegg's role was extremely funny and added humour to a very suspenseful film. Sean Harris, who plays the villain in this film was very creepy, which let the audience know he could not be trusted, and that the other characters should be very careful. Rebecca Ferguson's performance was very good, as it manipulated the audience many times as to whether she was a friend or an enemy. Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation's action scenes were very thrilling, and constantly tense, almost as if the audience were really there. For example, the motorbike chase and the underwater scenes were extremely fascinating. Also, during the final scenes in particular I found myself holding my breath, because of the fact that they were laced tension. What I didn't like about Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation was the fact that there were many cheesy lines and moments that left me cringing in my seat, although I suppose they could have been worse, and I kind of did expect them from an action film. Overall, I did enjoy this film, however it felt like there was something missing but I cannot put my finger on it. This film is enjoyable for all ages, but maybe a bit harder for younger children to follow.

Mission Impossible- Rogue Nation is not necessarily the smartest film of the bunch (I would hand that to the first two of the series), nor is it the most over the top crazy (Ghost...). It just may be the most complete and well constructed film of the bunch though.The film takes a decidedly introspective turn as it exposes its age (the premise revolves around a legal case to dissolve the IMF and bring its members to justice after all these years of reckless tendencies; the film 'reassembles' an old team that has been unofficially retired; and lastly, the film glorifies some well placed shots of Cruises grey hair without shame). It also examines the tendency (and perhaps accusation) that this film is simply a showboat and ego trip for Cruise to showcase himself (or in the film, for Ethan to wallow in his desperate attempts to defeat a single enemy at the possible expense of his team and of fuelling a larger war that could endanger a much wider population). There are two answers. The first one is an absolute yes, this series is completely about cruise. MI is Cruise as much as Cruise is MI. This is where he belongs.Throughout the series there has been a very fine line between who Cruise is in the real world and what he brings to the screen as the embodiment of Ethan. The opening scene in Rogue is the infamous plane scene, which is less a necessary part of the plot and more a statement on who Cruise is. There is something about his willingness to throw himself in to his own stunts and make them feel, seem, appear impossible that is endearing in a sort of reckless charisma kind of way, no matter your feelings on Cruise himself.The other answer to the question (of whether this project is all about Cruise) is a large no (or in the words of Ethan, "Do you really think that's what I'm about? Do you REALLY think that's what this is about !!?"). The main point of the film is about the concept of team (who all bring their own bit to the film). And even more so, the film brings in Rebecca Ferguson (as Ilsa Faust), who I hope we see more of in future films. She brings a wonderful flair to the sort of mysterious and enigmatic counter part to Cruises own roque tendencies, and is absolutely watchable on screen as she is talented at fight and flight sequences in her own right.In many ways this latest instalment is all about the idea of going rogue and the repercussions of becoming too one sided (or self focused). This is where the film starts, and the film slows down enough to allow some key moments to resonate in this regard. It comes out in the relationship between Ethan and Benji, and gets further questioned in the exchange between William and Luther. The film examines that difficult personal journey in dealing with our demons and exacting our own sense of justice in the face of those demons while also weighing the affects that our choices and decision can have (and do have) on others. This comes out in a poetic way in three choices that come out in an important exchange between Ethan and Ilsa, and it is also embodied in a poetic finish in which the nagging Cruise question comes full circle and is dealt with in a wonderfully incomplete fashion.Rogue is not unique in what is already a crowded series. How you feel about that might affect how much you allow yourself to enjoy this latest instalment. There are certainly a few points in which the familiar mission solving and riddled solutions that happen in the mind of Ethan and slowly get brought to light for the audience are slightly predictable. But there is a maturity and a refreshing familiarity to Rogue that sets itself apart, even aside from the fact that is pure entertainment and simply fun to watch on screen. There is something impressive about the fact that they allow Rogue to feel fresh and alive in its own right even without pushing it over the top (there are some cringe worthy moments and jaw dropping action sequences, but they are well tempered and well paced). A worthwhile entry in to what has become an impressively enduring series.

It's no secret that I'm not nearly the fan of the Mission Impossible series that everyone else is these days. Perennially overrated, I have found the series enjoyable generally but also fairly predictable and with a lead who has, in recent years, become increasingly unlikable. Nevertheless, Rogue Nation was one of the better additions to the series. Pairing the stunt happy Cruise with newcomer Rebecca Ferguson was a brilliant move, producing one of the better action sequences of the year so far in the well crafted opera house scene. The rest of the film is also quite exciting and despite successfully predicting every plot twist, the appeal of the Mission Impossible series remains the likable team and slick production value. Perhaps my biggest complaint was the repeated use of old Bourne and Bond tricks throughout the movie but in retrospect, there are worse films to copy. I'm genuinely looking forward to seeing this whole thing wrap up with the next film.

In conclusion, twisting the angle of genre cliches with a memorable villain and sharing Hunt's limelight with a compelling female lead to boot, Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation is a mission one should definitely accept. Bear in mind that its largest weakness comes post-climax. Amazingly, "sequelitis" for a film franchise on the cusp of being twenty years old isn't a dismal expected factor here.Mostly unimpressed with Christopher McQuarrie's previous Hollywood contribution, directing and penning 2012's Jack Reacher (an adaptation of Lee Child's 2005 novel One Shot), I was going to pass on Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation. Although noticing that McQuarrie had compared Rogue Nation to Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight (citing it as an influence for the antagonist), piqued my curiosity. On the contrary it simultaneously deadened my interest too. Frankly, Rogue Nation gave me what The Dark Knight had promised in a stronger less absurd package. Yes, without hesitation I prefer and will set Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation on a higher shelf always than The Dark Knight. In other words, check out Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation ASAP.

There is something to be said about Tom Cruise. Why he has the best track record with blockbuster films, why he's as good now as he was 20 years ago, or why we want to keep seeing him in movies. To be honest, he doesn't have the likability of a Will Smith, or the brooding persona of a Harrison Ford, and it makes no sense, but we can't take our eyes off of the screen when he's there. He doesn't beg for our attention, but he gets it. Maybe it isn't that certain zeal or infectious energy. Maybe it's that ability NOT to monopolize the screen. This allows others around him to shine. He doesn't ask for our approval, so we're more willing to give it to him. He's seldom your favorite character in a given movie, but at the same time he carries every film that he's in. And he's been doing it for over three decades now.Mission: Impossible Rogue Nation is no different. The supporting cast is great in this film, but without Cruise, it would just waste away.As the CIA has disintegrated the IMF (Impossible Missions Force), Ethan (Cruise) and his team attempt to eradicate the Syndicate--an international organization lead by Solomon Lane (Sean Harris) whose agenda is to acquire enough money to colonize their own rogue nation.There aren't any real callbacks to the previous films--something that they may be doing in attempts to be more Bond-esque, but for fans hoping to get more of what they love in the previous 2 films, they're in for a treat. The action and fight sequences are jaw dropping, and the premise is so well-conceived that you won't ever know what's coming next. It can get a little heavy in the details, but you just accept everything and follow along, and it all makes sense in the end. Jeremy Renner (Williams Brandt) and Simon Pegg (Benji Dunn) return, and so does Ving Rhames (Luther) after his absence from the last film (not including a brief cameo). Rebecca Ferguson (Ilsa Faust) is a great addition to the franchise, and I hope that her mysterious character is developed more in future installments.It may not reinvent the wheel, but its non-stop action never makes you realize that it's nearly two and a half hours long. Christopher McQuarrie acts as both director and screenwriter for this film--a feat that I feel does wonders for a project. And he now has a great addition for his CV.Twizard Rating: 97

MI: Rogue Nation is an adrenaline filled thrill ride. Tom Cruise does almost the same character in every movie, but it's an entertaining one. I'm a huge fan of quite a few people in this film. Cruise, Pegg, and Renner are among my favorites. They are all leads in their own movies, but they work well together as a couple of them take more supporting roles. There's not a lot of depth to the story, not many plot twists, but it is enough to keep the action sequences going. The next MI has been green lit and I'm already excited for it. In the meantime, rest assured you will have Rogue Nation to enjoy while they start writing the next. Definitely worth seeing.

However with this particular franchise, I found it quite easy to understand. The action was top notch, no question. I enjoyed it immensely especially with Plane scene at the beginning. Me with a fear of flying, I actually felt I was actually on the plane. So real it was. hahaah. My fav scene thou was with the Prime Minister(Hollander) and Atley(McBurney) when Atley's face was 3D Printed ontop Ethan Hunt's(Cruise) face. I thought that was class. When Prime Minster claims that Brandt's(Renner) hand is "So warm". We all got a great laugh. Brandt looks over at Atley/Hunt and hunter shows the face as much as to say deal with it. I thought it was class.So now onto the plot. The plot as I says above quite simple. Ethan Hunt(Cruise) stumbles upon a group known as the Syndicate who has been described as: "An Anti-IMF",who's job is to take down the IMF and all that goes with it. It all starts off as I said above the plane scene. You'd wanna have a head for heights, no question. Anyways, Ethan gets onto the plane with the help of Ethan's buddy Benji(Pegg). Then afterwards a LOVELY score. It really was like a TV Series type as I actually learned of this lately. Hunley(Baldwin) wants to disband IMF competly and appears in a US Senate Committee. Classic line from Brandt is "I can neither confirm nor deny any details without the permission of the Secretary".He continuously states this when asked by the Committee. So a series of events occur. The Vienna Opera scene was a classic scene too. The Chancellor of Vienna is assassinated. I don't get the connection to it. They did explain the Istanbul and all the majors terrorist attacks. But that's about all I understood.2D - Sound spectacular.Pls note there are no extra scenes BEFORE the credits or AFTER

It's official, Ghost Protocol has rebooted MI into a smashing action/espionage success with this follow up.RN is everything you need in an action film. Great set pieces, smart plot, clever humor, somewhat relateable/humane characters, a robust competent cast, good direction...I almost feel like it's too similar in quality to GP though. The pacing, action, dialogue, even the way each character moves almost seems surgical now. Don't get me wrong it's a great film and like I said, everything you'd ever NEED but I think we've hit a level of stagnation here.There's no more wow factor, there's nothing iconic that you would recall for years on down the road. Rogue Nation will be remembered by most as a blur of exceptional action film making...I believe the next MI film will need more personal, resonating character moments from the IMF crew if it's going to succeed.

The longest running international spy of 18 years is now a fugitive who is sought by the CIA for inevidently saving the world. Ethan Hunt's impossible mission, whether or not he chooses to accept it, will be to survive and of course, save the world from a rogue organization that had its inception within the IMF. With some commendable dedication to not just the stunts and action but also to the production of this franchise, Tom Cruise returns to the role that he is most comfortable with and is most appreciated for. Christopher McQuarrie ('Jack Reacher') takes the reigns of directing this time and brings back the intricacies and guile in Brian De Palma's 'Mission: Impossible'. With some exemplary action sequences, smart protagonists, an intricate plot of deceiving espionage and some desirable futuristic high tech, Ethan Hunt is here on a mission to entertain and as usual, he does it in style. Hunt and his team have just intercepted a terrorist cell flying out with a stash of nerve gas missiles on an A-400 cargo plane. The seemingly death-defying stunt is what makes Tom Cruise among the most watchable action stars and soon afterward, his suspicion about a discreet terrorism funding organization called the Syndicate becomes real when he is kidnapped by one of their members, the bone doctor. His escape is aided by an undercover operative named Ilsa Faust (Rebecca Ferguson) who might have more to reveal about the Syndicate. Meanwhile, owing to their previous interceptions including the recent one at Kremlin that caused massive collateral damage, a committee of Senators agree with CIA director Alan Hunley's (Alec Baldwin) testament to disband the IMF to make it a part of CIA. Hunt is now on a run from the CIA, without his team and with limited resources.There are several mysteries that he needs to uncover including the identity of the man he encountered at one of their hideouts and his link to the Syndicate, Ilsa's true intentions and allegiance, the retrieval of the encrypted drive and its disruptive contents. Each sub-plot gets further entangled in the other, with the rogue Syndicate threatening to unleash terror forces all over. It will take more than just Ethan's will to succeed in this mission that's shrouded in mystery like the London fog in the climax. Impossible, but doable.  The storyline, although convoluted at times, strives to be opaque like in Brian De Palma's version, which is a good thing because the mystery adds an enduring value. Every sub-plot and every character unify to a sensible conclusion with the occasional humor and sarcasm to ease through the twists. Some of the action sequences are frenetic and some just gravity defying. Cruise still chooses to perform most of the stunts by himself and that is quite commendable. Apart from the aircraft hanging scene, the film's highlight is definitely in Morocco. After the gripping sequence in the underwater server station, the action moves to the streets of Casablanca with Hunt and Benji in a thrilling car chase with superbikes in hot pursuit. The sheer adrenaline can be felt throughout the sequence as the BMW roars through every sharp corner and straight. This is followed by a superlative bike chase through the mountains which makes up for all the money's worth by itself. Then, to add to the eeriness of the sub-plots, the climax in London's foggy streets takes us back in time to some Hitchcock style thrills as Ilsa has a knife fight with the bone doctor. The other Hitchcock inspired sequence, the assassination attempt at the Opera in Vienna, is among the film's most adroitly executed ones.  At age 53, Tom Cruise still has the ability to be all over the screen. His commendable efforts go beyond just the stunts that he chooses to carry out on his own. He has immersed himself deep into the role of Ethan Hunt, embodying the charming spy who almost gets himself killed every half hour. Cruise's dedication to this franchise is necessary for both its running as well as his own career. No matter who or what he is off screen, he is a remarkable entertainer as agent Ethan Hunt, whose impossible missions keep us hooked in awe. Simon Pegg as the techie side-kick is geeky yet funny enough for us to care about his survival. Jeremy Renner's Brandt is always in a spot between the CIA and his commitment to Ethan's crew and he balances things pretty well. Alec Baldwin has some cheeky lines and adds the right amount of gravitas to his character as a CIA director. The surprise act of the film however is Rebecca Fergusson as Ilsa Faust. She is vibrant, kicks ass in action sequences and is just an equal match for Ethan without being an unnecessary interest of another kind.  Fingerprint verification on car windows, encrypted flash drives that require the Prime Minister's authentication, high tech gadgets and of course, those crazy masks to change identities, make this a thoroughly exciting espionage film. The plot is thick enough to keep you engaged yet not contrived to just fill in gaps between action sequences. Rogue Nation is what Bond films used to be like. It's a complete entertainer by all means and among the most satisfying action films of the year that also enables Tom Cruise to keep this franchise alive. Light the fuse people...........9.113 on a scale of 1-10.

Each Mission: Impossible film pushes more than the previous mission. The first "Mission: Impossible" was the update of the 60s' TV series that introduced the characters and their methods. Four years later, "Mission: Impossible 2" focused more on the action and was the first mission to push things up a bit, and it was also the first of the series becoming just Tom Cruise's extreme, action-packed vehicle. Six years later, "Mission: Impossible III" done a farther push with more thrills and a little more action whilst balanced. Five years later, "Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol" strengthen the push further. Now four years later, the latest mission "Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation" push it all the way to the point of challenging and twisting the traditional elements with unpredictable outcomes.The position "Rogue Nation" put itself among the films is being the best when challenging what's been known and displaying the best of its ways of being entertaining. Before describing what kind of play it'd played, it's worth pointing out that this installment is a throwback to the second installment with similarities. The second installment was the least received of the series, but provided action sequences that were one of the respective genre's best. So as the latter was balanced with the action and small attention to the substance, the latest mission improves it with more excitement and thrills through the twists to the known style, otherwise inadvertently erasing it.The way it was pushed was done with complex writing that was well-handled to make things such as the twists and quick action work, as well blending in some comic without losing concentration. With the concentration unbothered, thrills were resulted. But there's another source that fills those description that made this a great movie is the great cast, with the returning Cruise, Rhames, Renner and Pegg with the additions of Rebecca Ferguson and Alec Baldwin. The obvious standout is the driver himself, Tom Cruise. His performance and stunts should get him at least be recognized for a nomination for Best Actor as he felt the real adrenaline that channels him whilst performing. Also, give an Oscar contender to director Christopher McQuarrie as his direction helped the pushing as well."Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation" is the best Mission yet by pushing the style of the action and intelligent complexity writing to crack the limits to generate the thrills, excitement and occasional humor, and the cast performed well to stay at that level. Now, it's your mission, should you choose to accept it, to see this before it gets minimized for available viewings on smaller screens since the kind of scale this Mission has is a big-screen ride. (A+)

One for the popcorn lovers. So the IMF agency has been disgraced and terminated by the CIA. Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) is still in the field. With no cavalry coming, it's up to him to take down the shadowy group of people known as the Syndicate, a band of criminals that to this day, has not even been proved to have even existed. Speaking from a personal standpoint, I am only familiar with the most recent movies in this series. I missed 3, and I watched 1 and 2 at some point long ago, but I really can't recall anything as far as specific details go from either of them, except the theme music. Now you would think that that my lack of familiarity may cause me to view these movies more distantly, but it's quite the opposite, really. I've said it before, and I'll say it again: Ghost Protocol, the fourth film, is one of the best action films of the last 5 years, and I stand by that statement. So how does Rogue Nation stack up against it? It's good, but not as great. This is still fun, don't get me wrong. This is a series that is all about the set piece, and when Rogue Nation is being a straight action movie, that's when it shines the brightest, keeping you entirely in the moment. The action is all well thought out and makes sense (for the most part, but I'll get to that in a bit), but where this installment runs into issues is in the story department. Rogue Nation pulls of the difficult feat in that it is simple and convoluted at the same time. They make this so much more complicated than it needs to be, and I would be lying if I said that it didn't drag the film down as a whole quite a bit. When it slows down and stops being action-y, you can't help but notice the number of flaws in the storytelling. The fifth Mission: Impossible movie is much less about the team and much more about Tom Cruise, which is unfortunate, because they had just fixed that in Ghost Protocol. They give Jeremy Renner much less to do, which is also a shame, because the series was primed to have the reigns handed over to him. The villain is kind of bland, and there are a couple of instances where the suspension of your disbelief is pushed past the limit. For example, there's a car crash where all parties should have died, and even if you can blur your eyes and get past that, it is followed by a high speed motorcycle wipe-out where there is barely a scratch on Ethan Hunt. I know that it seems like I'm being harder on this than I actually ended up feeling about it, but these are things that I couldn't in my right mind go without mentioning. If you can overlook all these flaws, there's enough good featured here to have a fun time, and my rating reflects that.

In an age of CGI robots, apes, and (digitally enhanced) superheroes, it's nice to know that Tom Cruise is still the best special effect money can buy. In Hong Kong cinema, this may be a staple, but rarely on this side of the world do we have an actor willing to throwing caution to the wind (literally) to entertain an audience. Christopher McQuarrie (VALKYRIE, EDGE OF TOMORROW) is a solid writer (and I am an admitted fan of both WAY OF THE GUN and JACK REACHER), but one can't help but feel at times that he was overwhelmed as a director. A good ole-fashioned Spy Flick was the aim, but McQuarrie, Cruise, and company fall a bit short - especially in comparison to the solid MI:III and MI:GHOST PROTOCOL. That being said, one should appreciate, and hope for more, creative hyper-realistic-in-camera action spectacles that this film and the phenomenal MAD MAX: FURY ROAD provide over the bloated cartoons that audiences have grown accustomed to.

I've been skipping movies lately, but I couldn't pass up on this one. I haven't seen a bad Mission Impossible movie ever and this is no exception. This one plays like a suave James Bond movie, particulary The Spy Who Loved Me (which is a personal favorite) wherein the protagonist and antagonist develops a sort of liking for each other. Excellent stunts, action sequences and direction. (It's amazing how Tom Cruise does some of his own stunts!) Great acting from Tom Cruise, Rebecca Ferguson and Simon Pegg (who was so funny!)

I do agree that Tom Cruise is now 54 and that doing those death defying stunts in that age and looking still in peak form at this stage is extremely commendable. But to overlook all that is not there in this film and the things it lacks only to cloud it up with the fact that "Oh Tom Cruise can do that even now!" is for audience that craves for popcorn flicks. Rogue Nation is entertaining but it is surely not the best in the franchise. Infact I feel Mission Impossible 3 with its mind games and an excellent act by Seymour Hoffman was better. Ghost Protocol certainly was. Rogue Nation opens with a brilliant sequence but just not as brilliant as the ones we have come to expect from the series. The "impossible" stunt of the underwater dive is good too but then again it pales in comparison to the thrills the Burj Khalifa act in Ghost Protocol gave. The film also suffers from a very un-intimidating villain and a not so threatening impending sense of doom.Jeremy Renner and Rhames are reduced to sidekicks though Simon Pegg gets some moments of comic timing though even that doesn't compare with the previous films. The surprise however is Rebecca Ferguson who plays the cold hearted yet vulnerable MI6 agent to the hilt. Finally it is Cruise who almost single handedly sees the film through and though it maybe peppered with ordinary bike chases, stunts and weakening humor it is still a pretty good film to enjoy. Ghost Protocol still rules the roost.

Why do action movies have to be silly-funny now? Remember the first M:I? I preferred that. Same thing happened with the Terminator saga, for example. Apart from certain decent action scenes and respectable acting, this movie has nothing new to offer.

I mean, so good, had I the taste for popcorn I'd have been filling my face by the bucket load. Easily the best of the franchise, excellent jobs by all involved, Simon Pegg in particular, and excellent cinematography and direction that captures all the action in a way that doesn't leave you dizzy - just exhilarated. That opening sequence though...totally nuts, all Tom Cruise, and gets the heart to a pace that never lessens for the next two hours.

Mission Impossible Rogue Nation is the fifth MI film to date. I'm sure there'll be more down the line. If you liked the last four MI films, particularly Ghost Protocol, you will get a kick out of this as it's more of the same. All the characters from Ghost Protocol reprise their roles here with the exception for one and they added another woman to replace her. The story is very simple. Ethan Hunt returns once more played by Tom Cruise along with his team from the last film save one. This time around he is hunting for a rogue organization called the Syndicate. The Syndicate is an organization that consists of former intelligence operatives who had been reported missing or dead which commits heinous acts all across the world in secret. Before Hunt can track them he is captured and IMF is shut down. However, a mysterious woman saves which leaves Hunt with her as his only lead to find the Syndicate.  All the actors like Tom Cruise, Ving Rhames, Simon Pegg, Jeremy Renner, etc. all do fine work as usual. Tom Cruise is at top form which is impressive considering he's in his late fifties now. He still does his own stunts which is crazy. Alec Baldwin is also in the movie as the head of the CIA and he does fine for what he had. The new girl they got for this, Faust (Rebecca Ferguson), also did a good job and kicked some ass. As usual all the characters are likable and have great chemistry. I also like the villain this time around. Usual the villains in these movies aren't the best. While this villain doesn't have any depth per say (they go into him a bit but not much) but he's very charismatic, smart, and poses quite the challenge for Hunt and his team. The villain here might be the strongest of the franchise so far.The action and effects were blood-pumping as usual. You also have your complex impossible break-in operation you see in each of these movies which are always fun to watch and this is no exception. The final action scene I thought was lacking a bit though compared to some of the other films.Though, there are a couple minor things for me. For one I'm getting a bit sick of the whole "going rogue" thing where Ethan and his team are on the run from IMF or, in this case, the CIA. In practically all of these films you have Ethan going rogue and is one the run from his own government while trying to stop the main villain. Even many of the recent James Bond movies have done this to death. Don't get me wrong, I'm a big fan of the whole lone hero or heroes versus the world trope. However, even awesome clich�s become stale when abused too much.Also I wish these films would go more into Hunt as a character. Even the recent Bond films have begun diving into his past including the latest one coming out Spectre. That might be a nitpick for a film like this but some character moments definitely wouldn't hurt. Overall if you are a fan of this franchise than you will enjoy this film. It does everything the other films have done and did them well. If you liked the fourth film especially you should like this if not love it.

IN DE PALMA THEIR HANDS - My Review of MISSION IMPOSSIBLE: ROGUE NATION (4 Stars)Sometimes, and I mean rarely, a blockbuster well into its franchise just works. Think about how CASINO ROYALE reinvigorated the 007 Series, with Daniel Craig and director Martin Campbell bringing a healthy dose of gravitas to something that had long-before resorted to trashy silliness. But, again, that kind of thing happens as often as Halley's Comet. Imagine my surprise then when writer/director Christopher McQuarrie and Tom Cruise reunited for this fifth installment and went in guns blazing. This is a thrilling action movie, effortlessly jumping from set piece to set piece with deliciously shifting loyalties and some tightly-wound suspense. It's not going to change the world, but it definitely sends a warning shot to all the other Studio Tentpole makers to up their game and at least stay engaged with the swill they're shilling. MISSION picks up a short time after the Kremlin-destroying events of GHOST PROTOCOL, with our hero, Ethan Hunt (Cruise) desperately trying to get to a plane before it takes off. Yes, the filmmakers blow their poster wad within the first five minutes, giving us that indelible and real shot of Cruise dangling from the side of a plane in mid-air. My instant thought was, "That's pretty ballsy. I hope they have more tricks up their sleeves or else this thing is an early climaxer!"Turns out, it was just an appetizer, and when we come back from credits, we find the IMF (Impossible Mission Force) in disarray and losing its power, with Hunt having gone dark in the field. A perfect time for the Syndicate, a band of terrorists hellbent on world domination, to set their plot in motion. Of course they have to go through Ethan and his loyal band of spies, and we all know how that tends to work out for the bad guys. Joined again by Jeremy Renner, Simon Pegg and Ving Rhames, Cruise and company find themselves in a race against time to save the world. The story, as usual, is somewhat irrelevant, but the execution of the thrills and chills thoroughly won me over. Without spoiling anything, we're treated to torture, an attempted assassination at an opera, a thrillingly-edited underwater sequence, and a good half dozen more scenes before the film almost literally dumps you out, spent and exhausted. Bringing an ambiguous dose of tension is Rebecca Ferguson, excellent as the femme fatale who may or may not be on Ethan's side. It's this push-pull that gives the film its effervescent kick. I've enjoyed Cruise's performances in recent years because he's become more willing to give us the aging action star who suffers aches, pains, and real fear. He may ultimately prevail, but there's a cost nowadays. Battle fatigue often plays better than superhuman strength, something the world of MARVEL and DC COMICS could stand to learn. Beautifully shot by master cinematographer Robert Elswit, who ruled 2014 with stellar work on NIGHTCRAWLER and INHERENT VICE, and edited with rare patience by Eddie Hamilton, ROGUE NATION seldom resorts to the style of seizure-inducing scenes in most giant CGI nightmares. Instead, much effort has been put into understanding each location and who is doing what to whom. Trust me, that just does not happen much anymore. McQuarrie also gets credit here, using alternate scenarios to get what's normally droning exposition across to the viewers. The preparation for the underwater scenes, for example, made great use of dispensing complicated information by way of showing Simon Pegg suffering the outcome of a mission that could go horribly wrong. This and the stunning opera scene reminded me of vintage Brian De Palma, who in addition to making such suspense classics as DRESSED TO KILL and BLOW OUT, happened to direct the first MISSION installment. De Palma understands screen geography better than most and he's always infused his scenes with a somewhat winking, knowing, dreamlike energy. McQuarrie seems to pull from the same playbook, perhaps to honor his predecessor's work on the series, or maybe it's because he just thinks De Palma has done cheese correctly. Either way, what we have here is very De Palma-esque. For a director like De Palma, who has often been criticized for being too Hitchcock-esque, MISSION IMPOSSIBLE: ROGUE NATION seems to give him his long-deserved due...even if he had nothing to do with it.

Unless you're just obsessed with watching cars all the time (The Fast and the Furious films), the Mission: Impossible movies have become the best action franchise out there. You get something different in each film. Although the one constant is Tom Cruise pretty much breaking his body to impress the audience. He's now 53 years old and still doing his own insanely risky stunts that other actors won't do. People raved about the last Mission: Impossible reinvigorating the series, but that one really just had two big elaborate scenes and a completely unmemorable villain. The newest entry in the series surpasses that one in my opinion.Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation, like the others before it, has what sounds like a convoluted plot but winds up being easier to follow as it goes along. And as always, the unique action scenes distract you from any concerns you may have about the plot anyway. This time around, the IMF agency that Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) and his team work for has been disbanded and now absorbed into the CIA. This is due to the IMF's extreme and sometimes unacceptable methods of operating, as well as Ethan Hunt's insistent belief in an international criminal organization known as the Syndicate which leads him to being cutoff by the CIA.So know Hunt is perceived to be on his own as he's missing in action from their last operation. With the CIA after him, he now has to worry about his own country which he once worked for as well as a new adversary named Solomon Lane who heads that very Syndicate which he has been trying to eradicate. Solomon is a chilling, malevolent antagonist to Hunt as he captures him early in the film. Luckily, Ethan Hunt's fellow agents agree to help him out regardless of the IMF's disbanding. That's part of what has made the last three Mission: Impossible films in particular really work: they're not all about Ethan Hunt, but rather about how his team works so cohesively to help him complete his missions. But don't get me wrong, it's always Tom Cruise at the forefront. Other actors get their moment such as Simon Pegg who adds humor to all the crazy action. Yet it's Cruise who dazzles everyone with his game stunt work and dedication to the role. Whether it's holding his breath underwater for minutes at a time or literally hanging off the side of an actual airplane in flight, he always pushes the envelope and wows us. Regardless of your personal opinion of the man, he shuts his naysayers up when it comes to entertaining his audience with these films. You can expect more Mission: Impossible movies in the future as this is one of the only film franchises that continues to get better and better as it goes along.

In the last 10 years, I have sit through 4 of the Mission Impossible films and I loved them. Growing up Tom Cruise was The MI guy for me, that's how I knew him before anything else. So when MI:5 was announced I was very excited and I wanted to go back to all of them starting from MI: Ghost Protocol but doing that I realized that these movies were not memorable. I mean, I remembered how they made me feel but I hardly remembered any specifics about the movies. The other crazy thing was that some of them - MI:2 & MI:1 - didn't really hold up, that's when I started to get a bit worried about Rogue Nation.The storyline did little to subside my worries but I was mostly in, and what a surprise it was. Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation, is mindblowing, action packed, and gripping to the end. It managed to make me reevaluating the situation the whole way through. Nothing was exactly as they seemed or as I predicted, no matter how small it was there was always some details that I didn't see coming. I sometime watch movies with a clear ideas of what's coming and that doesn't stop me from enjoying these films - if the execution and the acting is solid - but in this case I only roughly guessed how things would play out. So there was room for surprises and I liked that.Speaking about surprises, Sean Harris was pretty good in the movie, I'm not saying that I'm shocked, but I was surprised to see him in a role like this and I'm glad he pulled it off. It's almost the same thing with Alec Baldwin, they managed to make his role a little bit more interesting than the stereotypical type these characters usually are. But the biggest surprise is Rebecca Ferguson, I still can't believe that it's the same woman from the mini-series The White Queen. She's fascinating and mysterious in the movie, not that the latest MI films have a bad track record with female leads but this one is probably the best out of all of them. MI: Rogue nation was a fun, entertaining movie going experience.@wornoutspines

Love him or hate him, you cannot deny that Tom Cruise is Box Office gold. Here we have the fifth movie in the franchise that started with a gamble on a live-action film version of a '60s TV show which, by all accounts have been continuing with each iteration to outdo the last. Where the 'Bond' movies seem to get worse and laughable as they continue, the 'M:I' movies seem to hit the mark each and every time as individual hits. This franchise is different in the fact that each movie can stand on its own with little backstory needed to get viewers up to date. Cruise, even in his early 50's, is as good if not better than most action stars half his age. As part of the writing team and the Director of this, his third movie, Christopher McQuarrie knows how to get the audience glued to the screen. With thrills, comedy and edge-of-your-seat action to boot McQuarrie completes the holy grail. This franchise has gone from strength to strength and is all the better for it. Each director has put their own original spin on the franchise. I remember when 'Ghost Protocol' came out, it hit all the right notes and became my favourite movie of the year. MI:5 has accomplished the same thing this year too. Everyone in this film is perfectly cast and kudos to the casting director for casting the actors in believable roles. Special shoutout to Sean Harris who is a perfect villain reminiscent of classic 'Bond'. Each scene is constructed to perfection and even in scenes where Hunt is close to death, I found myself in the theatre, tense and stressed over whether he would make it through or not. This movie is style defined entertainment at its best and Cruise never misses a beat. If this movie does anything, it solidifies the franchise as one of the greatest of them all deserving all the praise it gets. I for one will be front and centre for the premiere of MI:6.

After watching M:I 3, I lost hope for the franchise. Then I saw Ghost Protocol, and I gained my hope back. When I heard that Rogue Nation was in the works, I hoped that this movie would not be a waste of time. And thankfully, it wasn't. This movie is a fun joyride with amazing action and acting, and also includes an amazing cast of characters that bring this movie to life. This movie focuses on the IMF being shut down due to previous actions, and Ethan Hunt (played by Tom Cruise) is sent into hiding after being accused of being a terrorist. But the real terrorist is the evil group known as the Syndicate, who are wanting to create a new world order by executing a series of terrorist attacks. Ethan must gather his friends, Luther Strickell (played by Ving Rhames), William Brandt (played by Jeremy Renner), and Benji (played by Simon Pegg). They are also helped by former Syndicate worker Ilsa Faust (played by Rebecca Ferguson), and IMF agent Alan Hunley (played by Alec Baldwin). With this team, they attempt to stop Solomon Lane (played by Sean Harris) and his Syndicate group before they can commence these terrorist attacks. If you love the Mission Impossible movies, this is a must see, for it is one of the best of the franchise. It blends action and comedy together perfectly, and proves that Tom Cruise is still one of the best action stars ever. It also had some tense moments. I had a blast watching this, which is why I am giving it 4 1/2 stars.

Not many franchises get to a fifth sequel, and not many sequels warrant the price of admission, like the Saw movies or the Final Destination movies or the Resident Evil movies or the Scary Movie movies, etc. However, some franchises earn their sequels and thus deserve them, like the Fast And Furious movies, and Mission: Impossible has most definitely earned its fifth film. Rogue Nation may not obviously be the best M:I film and perhaps no M:I sequel can ever surpass the first movie, but this sequel is as strong, fun, and exciting as M:I:3 and M:I:4, and of course way better than M:I:2. Granted, that doesn't say much, but it still says something, and that thing is very positive. There is still life in this franchise and it seems like it's far from over, at least I hope. We go to the theater to see films like this because we want to have a good time while enjoying a good (well-made) movie, and not many films deliver. In fact, they often fail, and sometimes embarrassingly so. Thankfully, this franchise aims to please and pleasantly surprise with each sequel. Here's to the seventh film, cheers! :D I give Mission: Impossible: Rogue Nation an B+.

Tom Cruise hit on one hell of an idea when he decided to turn classic tv CBS series Mission: Impossible into a feature film that has spawned one of the more interesting and enduring film franchises ever. Cruise is producer as well as star and puts a new director in charge of each film. Since 1996, we've seen Mission: Impossible movies from Brian De Palma, John Woo, J.J. Abrams and Brad Bird (his Ghost Protocol remains the high point of the series). Cruise, now 53, can play IMF (Impossible Mission Force) undercover agent Ethan Hunt until he drops dead and I'm totally fine with that. Cruise is still a star incapable of slowing down, still running, jumping, climbing and fighting like a dude who has never stopped feeling the need for speed.Cruise returns for the fifth time and is no worse for wear in Mission: Impossible--Rogue Nation. The director this time is Christopher McQuarrie, who teamed with Cruise on the moody and intense Jack Reacher. McQuarrie has never dealt with material on this huge a scale, and the strain to amp up the action shows. The film starts with Ethan hanging off of the side of an Airbus A400M cargo plane during takeoff. Why? Who cares why in a rip-roaring franchise that has no place for logic.Yet McQuarrie, who won an Oscar for his amazing screenplay for 1995's The Usual Suspects, has plenty of aces up his sleeve. He brings a palpable indie sensibility to the big FX proceedings, but never skimps on t he wow factor, particularly in a motorcycle chase in Morocco and an underwater sequence that sees Ethan get help form his teammates Benji (a priceless Simon Pegg) and Luther (Ving Rhames). The plot, whatever plot there is, involves Ethan and Agent Brandt (Jeremy Renner) trying to save IMF from destruction by the CIA, led by a wonderful Alec Baldwin that is to bogged down by exposition-spouting dialog. Ethan knows a mysterious Syndicate is looking at taking over the world but no one else believes him.McQuarrie borrows philosophical elements from his own Usual Suspects when Ethan and Brit double-agent Ilsa Faust (Rebecca Ferguson, a real show stealer) takes on uber-creepy Solomon Lane (Sean Harris), a villain that could be a dead ringer for Keyser Soze. Harris, best known for his role on The Borgias, is no Kevin Spacey, and Rogue Nation is no Usual Suspects, but it has its best moments when McQuarrie lets loose his inner film geek and whips up an amazing shootout at the Vienna opera that is Hitchcock worthy. It's a knockout sequence like that, in which Cruise gives it his all as an actor and an athlete, that proves Mission: Impossible has plenty of juice left in it.
Good start to finish, delivered on it's promise. Highly recommend.

While the opening of the film featured a very cool stunt involving Tom Cruise actually hanging on the side of an airplane (with a huge strap digitally removed, of course) it was very abrupt and felt like any average action sequence from the series so far, so after that I wasn't very excited and had to wonder what this film had in store for the rest of it.Ethan Hunt faces one of his toughest challenges yet: instead of being called upon for a mission by IMF, his mission briefing at the beginning is actually a challenge by an organization known as the Syndicate, which is basically a "nation" of rogue agents who have joined forces, hence the title. While you think this would be a great premise for action and tension it doesn't really pay off until the third act, which I will get to later.The writers of this film really seemed to not know what they wanted from the leading lady. In the scene which introduces her, we understand she wants to help IMF though she is posing as a member of the Syndicate. She explains to Hunt that for him to continue his effort against the Syndicate she needs the Syndicate to trust her. After this, there are moments where it is clear she is on the side of the IMF team, though the writers through curveballs left and right for us to question her loyalty, which isn't confusing, just really annoying. It is even confusing when people from London come into play with her and they basically screw her over, ridding her of the Macguffin of the film, which they know she needs to earn the Syndicate's trust. Do they just want her dead? Did they plan that so the villain wouldn't get what he needs? So not only is it a question of who she is loyal to, but who really trusts her as well.The third act of the film is great, as one of the scenes is particularly tense - perhaps the most tense scene from the entire series, and the way the conflict of the film gets resolved is dark, clever, and fitting in that it parallels a scene at the very beginning of the film. I'm trying to avoid spoilers as much as I can, but you'll know what I'm talking about if you see the movie.Maybe I just have to rewatch this in order to appreciate it as a whole, but the third act of this film is probably one of the best third acts I've seen from an action film period. It is probably in my top 2 of the Mission Impossible series, though that isn't saying it's necessarily great, but pretty good.

This movie has it all. From the opening scene you are on the edge of your seat. I love how all these films (MI) make you think one thing and do another. I love the masks. There is a little love interest, great storyline, and non stop action.

More importantly, let's hope that agent Faust (Rebecca Ferguson) reappears for the next installment of MI. Also, I didn't realize that BMWs were so durable ......
