"Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation" is the latest (and arguably greatest) chapter in the 50-year-old Mission: Impossible franchise. While many franchises grow stale with time, this one has stayed fresh by shifting its focus from psychological mystery to non-stop action thrills. I do love the tone of the original 1996 film, but this shifted focus has allowed the Mission: Impossible series to evolve and stay relevant throughout several generations. This film builds on the momentum created by "Ghost Protocol" as the story travels to new exotic locations, introduces new gadgets, and continues to incorporate the classic mind games that define this brand of spy film. I worried that another Ethan-Hunt-must-take-down-the-bad-guys-to-prove-his-innocence concept would fall flat due to its similarity to other films in the series, but the real focus of this story is the changing perspective of whether Ilsa, a mysterious British agent, is a hero or a villain. The character is very well-written and Rebecca Ferguson embraces the depth of her conflicting motivations. Another interesting twist is that, rather than battle a terrorist, Ethan must take down an entire crime organization headed by the mastermind Solomon Lane. Lane is played by Sean Harris, who uses a quiet approach that somehow exudes an intimidating sense of power. Simon Pegg and Jeremy Renner reprise their roles to create continuity with "Ghost Protocol." One of my biggest issues with these films is that each one feels like a new world without connection to previous films, but this one truly felt like a continuation of the previous story. Once you add in Ving Rhames (whose presence was really missing in the last film) and carefully cast insignificant roles with actors who leave a strong impression (like Hermione Corfield as the record shop girl), it helps to make the far-fetched plot more believable. One of my biggest complaints is that, like other films in the series, the characters endure far too much physical damage to still be on their feet. I suppose this is just something that you have to accept with an action film. "Rogue Nation" will probably be most remembered for its high-speed motorcycle chase. I don't think I blinked or took a single breath until it was over. I was a bit disappointed that the highly-advertised stunt in which Tom Cruise actually hangs off of the wing of a plane as it takes off occurred in the first 3 minutes of the film; however, all was redeemed with the opera sequence in Vienna. It was genius to craft the scene around a gunshot to be fired during the high A in Turandot's "Nessun Dorma," one of the most famous notes in all of opera. I adored the stylistic shot in which they showed the note circled in the libretto, a clue that allows the musicians in the audience to anticipate the climax of the scene. If that wasn't enough to thrill me, composer Joe Kraemer brings the story full-circle by blending "Nessun Dorma" with the main theme during one of the film's most dramatic moments toward the end. These details will make it easy to rewatch the film, even once you know its twists. Just when you thought that it couldn't get any better, "Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation" shows that there is a lot left to be told in the story of Ethan Hunt. I can't wait to see where they go next.

Here's a little secret that a lot of screenplay writers don't know: ALL movies-no matter the genre, no matter the topic, no matter the setting-are action oriented. I'm not talking about gun battles and car chases and buildings imploding or scenes full of physical violence from the moment the credits roll, I'm talking about those smaller scenes where people . . . just talk. Yeah, that's what I said: there is (or should be) a ton of action, verbal action in scenes where people sit in chairs, stare at each other and just talk. I know! Revolutionary idea, right, that the "dialogue scenes" in Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation are just as action filled as that beautifully insane Moroccan motorcycle chase in MI5? Well, it's not really a "new" idea to make dialogue scenes "active." The ancient Greeks knew that the actor's voice with the right words to say could create in the audience's mind a wonderful sense of movement and activity. And the GREAT acting coach, Constantin Stanislavski, made this a major point in his teachings: Acting = ActionWriter (and director) Christopher McQuarrie delivers a script that is "nonstop" action. No, Seriously. Every scene is geared towards action. The characters are actively trying to accomplish something in an extremely active manner in EVERY scene. And whether it's the very intimate scenes when Ethan and the mysterious Ilsa try to figure out if the other is an ally or a deadly enemy, or the bigger than life scene where Benji pleads with Ethan to let him go into the field it's all an exciting/edge of your chair time for the audience. But as grand a script as this is, it also takes an extremely skilled group of actors to make it work. And this ensemble of Thespians (Okay, I just had to use the old high school term for theatre geeks at least once in a review) are working together like a well-oiled acting machine. There are no real stars here, and much to his credit Tom Cruise works extremely well fitting in with this group. But I have to single out one actor cause the character he created for this movie, Solomon Lane (which is real close to sounding like Robert E. Howard's character, Solomon Kane), is one scary frigging psychopathic villain. Listen, I'm an ex-Marine and Vietnam veteran (Okay, okay, I was a cook . . . Semper Fi; stir and fry . . . but still a vet.) and this character scared the crap out of me. It was a brilliant performance by English actor, Sean Harris.However, as wonderful as the movie is, there are a few glitches.1. Too many damn close ups! Don't you filmmakers get it? Close ups kill tension in a scene. It's that simple. And you shot most of this film in one of the most beautiful, intriguing places in the world, Morocco, and all you want to show me are close ups of the inside of Tom Cruise's nose? Okay, it is pretty nice the septum . . . but I'd rather see Morocco! So back that damn camera up!2. Extremely uninteresting hand-to-hand combat scenes. It's got to stop these uninteresting, chopped-up, unwatchable fight scenes. They really slow down the action. If the actor can't do the stunts, then hire someone who can. Or if the problem is you just don't know HOW to shoot a fight scene, go watch-John Wick (2015), Kingsman: the Secret Service (2015)-to see how it's done!3. Stop jump cutting intimate dialogue between characters. It's extremely annoying to try and follow intimate dialogue scenes when you keep jump cutting back and forth to each character when he/she speaks! There's a scene in a caf� when the MI Team sits around a table to discuss their strategy to take out the ever evil Syndicate and the camera keeps jumping back and forth, back and forth to whomever is talking. They do it ALL THE TIME! Again, it's annoying and totally uninteresting to watch from an audience member's point of view. Back the camera up, make it a static shot if you like, and just shoot the damn scene. Everybody doesn't have to be seen face-full just because they're talking. Although the above gripes are artistic ideals I'm passionate about . . . I really liked the script and the work of the actors in this movie. And it's saying something about the power of a good script and damn good acting when I can forgive technique faults.

Say what you will about his politics and "religion," Tom Cruise is undeniably one of the best action stars of the era. Mission Impossible continues to do the impossible, with each installment improving upon its predecessor and laying claim to new generations of action-starved fans. While most film series begin to experience massive franchise fatigue by their fifth installments, Rogue Nation leaves audiences begging for more.

Awesome, enthralling, brainy and more profound than its predecessors, "Mission: Impossible - Rough Nation" is undeniably a satisfying top-notch action flick - thanks to Christopher McQuarrie's directing and remarkable performance by Rebecca Ferguson and Tom Cruise.

While most of the setpieces (besides the Opera House scene) fall short of those seen in the previous installment in the series, it is still an incredibly entertaining, smart action movie that continues to show that Tom Cruise is unparalleled when it comes to action stars.

The fifth installment of the franchise, Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation delivers an exciting, adrenaline-packed adventure. After the IMF is disbanded secret agent Ethan Hunt goes rogue in order to complete one last mission to expose a criminal syndicate of former spies turned mercenaries. Tom Cruise, Jeremy Renner, and Simon Pegg return, and are joined by Rebecca Ferguson and Alec Baldwin. And their performances are pretty good; particularly Ferguson, whose stunt work and fight scenes are especially well-done. Director Christopher McQuarrie also does an impressive job, and brings a lot of suspense and tension to the action sequences. Thoroughly entertaining, Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation is an explosive spy thriller.

I have always been a big fan of the series thought felt John Woo did not do much for the second outing but was incredibly well recovered by J.J Abrams and Brad Bird.And with the Writer of my Favourite movie of all time "The Usual Suspects" Christopher McQuarrie behind the behind the Script and behind the camera it was sure to be something special and luckily there's very little to be disappointed out.That said many have called it the best in the series which I'm not entirely sure about but still is probably the best script of the lot of them with a cracking dialogue, original ideas, fantastic characters and the most chilling Baddie of the series so far played by Sean Harris!One character in particular Benji (Simon Pegg) is given tons of stuff to do and shows Pegg's serious acting talents that he should do more often.With all these films there is some fantastic action scenes with the biggest happening in the opening 5 minutes which in was did come as slight disappointment but the scene it self is stunning even more so as it was done for real by a very gutsy Tom Cruise!My only gripes with the film is though there is love about the script some things did come across as slightly predictable and both the opening and final scene before the credits needed one more extra beat to it but other than that this is a great little sequel and one that I know I want to catch a few more times on the big screen and pray Cruise and McQuarrie do another cracking Bluray Commentary like they did for the Jack Reacher Release!

Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation proves that there's still a lot mileage in the franchise yet. The MI movies with the exception of MI2 which was pants, are everything that you'd want from a summer blockbuster. The visuals are amazing, the stunts spectacular and it's got a good dose of humour to go with the espionage stuff. Even though there were a couple of Fast and the Furious moments (you know those moments in a film where you'd say to yourself, "yeah, they'd definitely die from that"), there's not too many so you can still suspend your disbelief which in compared to the Fast and the Furious movies your disbelief is suspended and sprang back in your face.Although over the course of the 19 years of this franchise there hasn't been much in the way of character development, Tom Cruise is still a bad-ass who seems to be looking for more and more extreme stunts to pull off with the passing of each installment. In this case he's hanging from a plane by his finger tips and involved in a high-speed motorcycle chase around Morocco wearing one of your Dad's Hawaiian shirts and a pair of shades. God knows what he's going to do next, he's not tried to French-kiss a killer shark yet, maybe he'll try that.As we know Cruise can now play Ethan Hunt in his sleep so the most surprising performances come from two of the fringe characters: Rebecca Ferguson and Simon Pegg. Rebecca plays a double age, or possible a treble agent depending on your definition and in this she is pretty much Ethan's equal when it comes to the action stakes. And Simon who has mostly been known as just the 'comic relief' in these movies delivers a much more rounded and likeable performance as the tech guy Benji (why he's named after a dog I'll never know).Speaking of dogs, does anyone else think that the Mission Impossible films are pretty much the equivalent to the modern day Indiana Jones (if you remember Indy was named after the family dog)?The only quibble about this movie and a couple of the other MI movies is the casting of the villain. In this movie I was never convinced by Sean Harris as Solomon Lane, the man in charge of the Syndicate. He looked more like an accountant then someone who could actually beat Hunt.

Wow - I've seen them all and by far this is the best. This guy is in his 50's and is known for doing most of his own stunts - did not disappoint. Plus there's bits of humor - it looks like everybody involved had a great time. Rebecca was amazing.

There have been only a handful of franchises(5 films or more) who have been able to both constantly reinvent themselves and also continue to find audience favour for their efforts. Fast and Furious, Bond Series and now Mission Impossible come to mind which have been to able achieve it and hence get Studios to greenlight future installments, sometimes even before the release of the latest one.Tom Cruise with his Scientology baggage, Oprah couch jumping, Katie Divorce et al has seen his Hollywood A lister stock plummet in the past decade and not so great domestic box office of his recent films like Edge of Tomorrow, Oblivion and Jack Reacher didn't help his case too.This janor of films always reach out to the arch nemesis to lift them beyond Zone Ordinary and to take example of Bond Films, Blofeld in the past or Javier Bardem as Raoul Silva, the villain in Skyfall or the menacing look of Christoph Waltz in the upcoming Spectre have achieved both for themselves and their films long lasting cult status.Sean Harris who had proved his acting chomps in Prometheus mesmerizes us all with his performance and trust me he does that with his voice modulation alone which leave an eerie after taste as you leave the theatre after this sumptuous feast. Thandie Newton's female lead in MI:2 which was both vulnerable yet strong, was my favorite in the series, but not any longer because Rebecca Ferguson plays her part with slither, charm and bravado and I hope Paramount can overlook past tradition and repeat the female lead in MI:6 as she brings such a layered performance to the table that all of us would love to peel more in the future instalments. Benji has the wittiest lines, Luther still packs the brawny charm while William plays the apprentice who shall likely take over when Tom Cruise is too old to hang off planes and buildings. Coming to planes, the Airbus A400 scene supposedly shot eight times without stunt double just to get it right doesn't awe and shock you like the Burj Khalifa cliff hanger in Part 5, though the customary "Steal the Impossible" set-piece did make you lose your breath as Tom held his own for beyond 3 minutes. In the era of Bourne and Craig led Bond, its a tribute that this franchise has held its own and shall challenge MI:4 for the worldwide Box Office crown.Tom Cruise has begun to look his age, but his face is the only place this film has wrinkles on and inspite of being 133 minutes long you don't find places, which may be trimmed.The action sequences score 8 and more out of 10 in the Thrillometer readings consistently from start to finish and Moroccan government should be paying lots of tax subsidies for the spurt in tourism they shall witness this year. As shooting begins next summer on the sixth part, we look forward to both Tom Cruise and the others (Rebecca :I am holding my breath for you!!) to present another cliffhanger to add shine to one of the most loved film franchises around.PS: Take home message for me is to scourge for earlier films of Rebecca and keep an alert for future appearances too.

When I was a kid I saw my first spy movie. It was amazing. It was complex, it had action and my dad had to watch it with me and carefully explain each characters motivation as I watched the lead man sift through supposed allies till he found true friends and that those he should have been able to trust the most had betrayed him completely for worldly reward. It's twist and turns left me dazed and I've never forgotten how it made me feel to watch this creature. It was so different than the classic stories I had been told and read and watched so far in my life. It was like a bee that had stung me, It strangely hurt to see how many times the hero was tricked into thinking himself safe then watching him escape the deathtraps they immediately dumped him into. But you never do forget how that bee sting felt. This bee sting was called mission impossible and after watching the fifth one tonight I can say that this franchises claim as one of the lead spy movies is dead. That bee is gone. It has squished itself into a new mold and spread itself thin to fit the shape of a new bug that has taken over the movie screen, the butterfly. We have all the new components of this new mold in their entirety however. The lead action man, tom cruise, on the verge of being too old for anything but the sort of stories where he defies his age to prove everyone wrong, especially the hot new spy recruit that will one day take his place (p.s. I am almost certain that this will be the premise for the last mission impossible movie sometime in the future.) The villain, with the almost incomprehensible accent and way of speaking that is meant to distract from the fact that he is not threatening to look at in the least. There are scary Russians, perfectly chiseled Germans and a seductive mystery woman in a flowy dress who the lead will almost seem to chase more than the main villain (p.s. is Ethan still married or was the revelation at the end of the last movie supposed to show how they weren't together anymore? I personally need a little more clarity on the matter and not just the comforting thought that there was only an oddly plutonic hug at the end of this film). There is even Jeremy Renner, the old man that almost looked young enough to take over the action film genre but couldn't quite convince everyone. This film even had a wonderfully funny British man to scream every time the lead man does something reckless (p.s. I actually really liked him, I think Simon peg was one of the best things to happen to this franchise as they almost seemed to be heading down a DC comics "no jokes allowed" route) However, as much as mission impossible has attempted to spread itself into the butterfly/marvel mold, this movie was like watching the drifting embers of a once powerful fire. It is beautiful in its own way but it is only a beautiful something that was once something else and has lost all of its former heat. The moral dilemma is gone, the betrayal is gone, and even a lot of exposition seems to be gone. Seriously though, It was like one long tricky chase scene where someone says, "we have to do this" someone else says "why?" then the first one answers "it's the only way" and he's off and people die. The classic, frantic thought at the end that there is no way out and the last minute split decision by the lead that saves everyone is gone now and simply replaced by an end where the good guys just find the most clever way possible of the tricking the villain. So go on, go watch a movie where Ethan hunt forgets how to slide across the hood of a car then remembers how to go on a high speed motorcycle chase. It was actually really good. just no longer a spy movie.
there's no real and new message in that movie. though it is always nice to see cars blowing up in the air and a man clinging to departing airplane .

Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation was fun, if a little dumb and convoluted. The movie doesn't exactly break new ground, but it has good laughs, good action scenes, and dynamic, charismatic characters. Yeah, even Tom Cruise. Admittedly, I'm a little disappointed that the main cast is such a sausage fest, but at least they worked off of each other well. A lot of scenarios got resolved in manners far too implausible to be credible (and anyone bringing up the title as a counter-argument will be punched) and the extent to which coincidence played into the success of their plans got a little tiring. But hey, it's Mission Impossible, so it's got enough action, intrigue, and rubber masks to keep me entertained. By my own admission, I haven't seen Mission Impossible III or Ghost Protocol, but this movie was good enough that it got me interested in seeing them. If you're down for a decent dick flick, I say check it out if you've got spare time.

"I've heard stories about you, but they can't all be true." It's understandable for someone within the "Mission: Impossible" universe to say this, skeptical of the many adventures of Ethan Hunt. In what may be the most consistently exciting franchise ever, he has been thrown onto a moving train, leapt between two skyscrapers, and scaled the tallest building the world, and that's only a few of his escapades. With Rogue Nation, the high-octane stunts-extravaganza is continued with operatic skill and thrill. What should be just another generic spy film is made cheer-worthy through crowd-pleasing action and loads of slick fun.Much of the success rests on Cruise's shoulders. He is easily one of the most committed stars in Hollywood, continuing the wonderful 2015 trend of practical effects, doing many of his own stunts. Our hearts pound because we sense the very real danger these people are in. Though Rogue Natiion may not have the single greatest combat scene in the franchise, it gives you the most bang-for-your-buck, rarely letting up long enough to let you catch your breath. When it does slow down, the tension is often cut beautifully by the cast, whose comedic beats between the excitement bring a nice respite.Otherwise, when the movie quiets down, the specifics of the plot and the not-intended-as-comedy dialogue drag a bit. Some mild cutting of superfluous scenes, specifically when focused on the weak villain and when unnecessarily objectifying the one woman, would've helped with the over-length. Mostly, though, the visuals, humor, stunts, and brilliantly iconic music kept me smiling throughout. Your mission, if you choose to accept it: see Rogue Nation.

Given the critical and commercial success that Mission Impossible: Ghost Protocol enjoyed a few years ago, it was inevitable that Cruise would be back for another instalment of the franchise. And so once again it's up to Ethan Hunt to save the world from international terrorists. And this time he'll be doing it as Washington's most wanted man. Hardly has the movie even begun before Impossible Missions Force is disbanded and absorbed by the CIA, which promptly declares Hunt a rogue agent and orders him brought in. So with the CIA's best men on his trail, and precious little intel to help him, he has to track down and dismantle the shadowing international terrorist group known only as the Syndicate. A group that knows far more about him than he does about it. These are long odds even for Hunt, but then doing the impossible is his business.His best hope lies with Ilsa Faust, a former British agent with connections to the Syndicate and a seeming attraction to him. Played by the beautiful Rebecca Ferguson, she is a very interesting character. She's smart, seductive, and very good in a fight, but you never can tell who's side she's on, if anyone's. It's clear that she has her own agenda and it's hard to tell if anything she's saying is the truth. But she's the closest thing Ethan has to an ally, and he can't seem to resist the allure of a dangerous woman in need of help. The plot is surprisingly smart for a summer popcorn flick, with sudden twists and reversals worthy of a recent Bond or Batman movie. Of course both the good guys' and bad guys' plans are excessively complicated and their success relies on a degree of timing and luck that would be impossible in real life, but who really cares? The action and plot twists are so tautly paced and slickly executed that suspension of disbelief is never a problem. It is a bit tedious how quickly the movie resorts to the clich�d plot device of the incompetent/corrupt CIA, but thankfully that ends up going in an entirely different direction than expected, with major narrative and comedic payoff.The action is of course excellent, with well-staged shootouts and car chases aplenty, and an opening sequence that would do a Bond movie proud. It also goes without saying that there is plenty of the high suspense the series is known for, especially in the obligatory high tech infiltration scene. And lest things get too serious, the tension is balanced by a great deal of very effective comic relief. Simon Pegg is hilarious as always as Benjie, Hunt's high strung and not entirely field capable tech specialist; his reactions shots during the Moroccan car chase are absolutely priceless. Nor is the movie afraid to score laughs at its star's expense, even poking subtle fun at Cruise's limited stature. With its ever present sense of humor and occasionally self-deprecating tone, the MI franchise is well on its way to establishing itself as the lighter alternative to the current Bond series. All in all, Rogue Nation is stylish, smart, and self aware, with just the right blend of adrenaline, suspense, and humor. Between this film and Ghost Protocol, I'd say that Cruise, director Christopher McQuarrie, and Paramount have perfected their formula for wildly entertaining spy thrillers. Here's looking forward to the next installment.

MISSION: IMPOSSIBLE - ROGUE NATION is an fun, old school meets new school, spy action thrill ride that isn't just the best of the M:I pictures so far, it's one of the best films I've seen this year. ROGUE NATION begins some time after the fourth installment GHOST PROTOCOL and features Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) hunting down an underground criminal empire known as "The Syndicate." Hunt's seemingly reckless actions however incur the wrath of CIA director Hunley (Alec Baldwin) who has the entire IMF (Impossible Missions Force) shut down. Hunt, now considered a "rogue agent" must track down the leader of the Syndicate, Solomon Lane (Sean Harris) and with the help of Benji Dunn (Simon Pegg), Luther Stickell (Ving Rhames), William Brandt (Jeremy Renner), and a mysterious agent named Ilsa Faust (Rebecca Ferguson), prove the Syndicate's existence and take them down once and for all. The standout elements of the film for me by far is the action and Rebecca Ferguson's performance and Ilsa Faust. Rogue Nation features three of the most original action setpieces I've seen in recent years, and that's not including the thrilling opening sequence where Tom Cruise really did hang from the wing of an A400 (no CGI was used, Cruise not only strapped himself to the wing of the aircraft...he did it 8 times to get the perfect take.) The action is filmed very crisply and in an old school way, I didn't notice a lot of excessive cross cutting and quick flash editing, you got to see a lot of the action fluidly, whether they were motorcycle or fight scenes, many of these action scenes were choreographed like ballets, every movement precise. The action wasn't just action for action's sake, the action served the plot well and served to build tension between key events in the plot. I find that today, too many action films just have minutes upon minutes of mindless action that don't serve a purpose, Rogue Nation does not commit this offense I feel. Rebecca Ferguson stands out in a pretty solid cast. Tom Cruise is good as always as Ethan Hunt, who, in following the old school action movie feel writer-director Christopher McQuarrie gave this film, Hunt is shown as an old school action protagonist in that he is human, he gets hurt, you have actual doubts whether he can make it out of these situations alive (even though in the back of your mind you're convinced he's in no danger). More Indiana Jones and less superhero is how a like my action protagonists, to build effective tension in these movies, you have to have no doubt in your mind that your protagonist is mortal and capable of being beaten. Simon Pegg is excellent as Dunn, providing comic relief and a little bit of dramatic weight to the film. But it is Ferguson as Faust, an agent whose loyalities seem to switch on a dime, that stands out. She gives an intense performance and her character isn't just eye candy or someone for Hunt to chase, she's a character with a bit more dramatic depth than is usually found in this sort of character in a spy film, certainly she has greater depth of character than most "Bond girls." She's every bit Cruise's equal, she kicks much much ass, and she's beautiful, mysterious and intriguing to boot. Faust is the most interesting character in the film. If there's a weak link in the cast, it's Jeremy Renner as William Brandt, his character is pretty one note. Also, Ving Rhames and Luther Stickell needed more screen time, but a minor nitpick at most. What gives Rogue Nation an edge over most all other M:I films is the villain. While not memorable, Sean Harris plays an effectively creepy villain whose schemes are sure to make the audience hate him by the end. All of his actions seem to carry weight and that's what you want from a villain, you want to see that his actions can greatly affect the heroes. If I had two nitpicks with the film, it's in the pacing and elements of the story. The action is pacing so perfectly in the first two acts and the tension is palpable and built so well that after the big second act action finale, the movie suffers into a small lull for 10-15 minutes that's full of over exposition and over plotting. Up until then I felt the film did a good job allowing the audience to breathe between action sequences but I think this "catch your breath" part of the movie ran for too long. Also, Rogue Nation's story and setup borrow quite a bit from recent spy films, in particular elements of the recent Bonds (SKYFALL in particular) and CAPTAIN AMERICA: THE WINTER SOLDIER that it makes parts of the film seem a tad too familiar. Other than those, ROGUE NATION is a great action film that doesn't get too dark, but is effectively intense and gives you everything you could want from an old school action film but with modern new school settings and sensibilities. You need have to seen the other M:I films or the classic TV series to enjoy ROGUE NATION although there are plenty of winks and callbacks to those previous properties for fans to get a smile out of. I give MISSION: IMPOSSIBLE - ROGUE NATION a score of 4.75/5 stars (A).

This movie was a lot of fun to watch. In addition to the expected over-the-top stunts - which were amazing, by the way - the writing was witty and the performances were spot on. Without a doubt, this is the best movie from the franchise.
